The penalty for anyone who uses a vehicle without a valid insurance is a fine of up to $1000 or to imprisonment of up to 3 months or both, and a mandatory disqualification from holding a driving licence for at least 12 months, if convicted.  The penalty for anyone who keeps, uses or allow the use of a vehicle without a valid road tax is a fine of up to $2000, if convicted.  Your vehicle may also be impounded, and towing and storage fees will then be payable in addition to the arrears of road tax and penalty fees.      Source:LTA

content_question: I intend to sell my current vehicle and wish to transfer the "unused" balance of road tax to my new vehicle. Can it be done?
meta_description: The road tax of a vehicle follows the vehicle. Hence, when an ownership of a vehicle is transferred to another party, a... read more answers
content_answer: The road tax of a vehicle follows the vehicle. Hence, when an ownership of a vehicle is transferred to another party, any remaining road tax will also be transferred to the new vehicle owner.  Source:LTA

content_question: My vehicle has been stolen. Can I claim back the remaining balance of my road tax? What should I do when the vehicle is subsequently found?
meta_description: If your vehicle has been stolen, please make a police report. Once the Police classify the vehicle as \xe2\x80\x9cstolen\xe2\x80\x9d and LTA ... read more answers
content_answer: If your vehicle has been stolen, please make a police report. Once the Police classify the vehicle as \xe2\x80\x9cstolen\xe2\x80\x9d and LTA duly notified, the unused road tax will be refund to the registered owner automatically If the vehicle is recovered subsequently, please notify the Police of the recovery and renew the road tax of the vehicle at LTA accordingly. Pre-requisites for renewal of road tax such as having a valid motor insurance for the vehicle should be fulfilled.  Source:LTA

content_question: Will I be reminded of my road tax expiry?
meta_description: It is the vehicle owner's responsibility to monitor the validity of their road tax and ensure that he renews the road t... read more answers
content_answer: It is the vehicle owner's responsibility to monitor the validity of their road tax and ensure that he renews the road tax of his vehicle before it expires.  Road Tax Renewal Notice As a service, LTA will send a road tax renewal notice to the vehicle owner about one month before the expiry date. If you do not receive it 2 weeks before the expiry date, please call the Land Transport Authority at 1800 - CALL LTA or (1800 - 2255 582) for another renewal notice to be sent. If you are a SingPass holder, you can click here to make the same request online (under the heading 'Licensing').   GIRO Payment Schedule (for payment of road tax by GIRO) About one month before the GIRO deduction date, vehicle owner who has arranged for their respective vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s road tax to be renewed via GIRO will receive a GIRO Payment Schedule to inform him of the GIRO deduction date as well as the deadline to fulfil the pre-requisites.  Email Reminder Vehicle owners who have updated LTA on their email addresses will also receive an email reminder about one month before the road tax for their vehicle expires.   Additional Email Reminder Please visit eCitizen portal at http://www.ecitizen.gov.sg/Topics/Pages/Road-tax-How-to-renew.aspx if you wish to sign up for additional email alerts under \xe2\x80\x9cServices & Tools\xe2\x80\x9d.  Source:LTA

content_question: What should I do when my insurance coverage is insufficient for the road tax period?
meta_description: Before the road tax of a vehicle could be renewed, the vehicle must have valid motor insurance covering the entire road... read more answers
content_answer: Before the road tax of a vehicle could be renewed, the vehicle must have valid motor insurance covering the entire road tax renewal period. Please approach your insurance company to extend the insurance period if it is insufficient to cover the entire road tax renewal period.   Source:LTA

content_question: Am I allowed to install an aftermarket Daytime Running Lamp (DRL) onto my vehicle?
meta_description: Vehicles should only be installed with factory-fitted Daytime Running Lamps (DRLs) as the vehicle manufacturer would ha... read more answers
content_answer: Vehicles should only be installed with factory-fitted Daytime Running Lamps (DRLs) as the vehicle manufacturer would have designed the lamps to meet internationally recognised vehicle standards. For aftermarket DRL kits retrofitted onto existing vehicles, there are concerns that such lamps have the propensity to cause unwanted glare and distraction to other motorists on the roads. Therefore, the installation of aftermarket DRL kits is not allowed.  Source:LTA

content_question: Am I allowed to modify my car's bonnet?
meta_description: To replace the vehicle's original bonnet with an aftermarket one of a different material (e.g. carbon fibre), vehicle o... read more answers
content_answer: To replace the vehicle's original bonnet with an aftermarket one of a different material (e.g. carbon fibre), vehicle owners are required to provide supporting certifications or documents to prove that the replacement bonnet is specifically designed and manufactured for a specific vehicle make and model. Vehicle owners who wish to replace their vehicle's bonnet can submit an application with the following supporting information (in English) to the Vehicle Engineering Division of LTA, 10 Sin Ming Drive, Singapore 575701. a) An application letter (with vehicle registration number) indicating the replacement part(s) to be changed; b) Product catalogue or technical specifications of the replacement parts and its installation procedures; and c) Supporting certifications or documents showing that the replacement item is structurally sound and does not alter the frontal collision characteristics of the vehicle  Source:LTA

content_question: Are after-market light bulbs legal to be used for vehicles on the road?
meta_description: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) requires all designs of vehicle lights, including HID lights, to comply with the Roa... read more answers
content_answer: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) requires all designs of vehicle lights, including HID lights, to comply with the Road Traffic (Motor Vehicles, Lighting) Rules. They must bear approved markings to show that they comply with internationally recognised standards, such as those adopted in the European Union countries, Japan and the United States. The lights must also conform to their illuminated colour and intensity. For headlamps, the LTA requires every unit fitted on the vehicle to be capable of casting a white light to the front of the vehicle. The intensity and alignment of a headlamp must also be within the specified limits. The colour temperature of headlamps that bear approved markings should not exceed 4000K. We have, in principle, no objection to the use of after-market light bulbs on vehicles so long as such bulbs comply with the above requirements and are suitable for use on the vehicle concerned. We have evaluated some of OSRAM and Philips light bulb products for vehicles and have no objection to the use of OSRAM Silverstar, OSRAM Cool Blue, Philips Blue Vision, Philips Silver Vision and Philips Vision Plus as these models comply with ECE Regulation and bear the ECE markings. If vehicle owners intend to install after-market bulbs on the vehicles, we would advise them to consult the local agents for the models that are suitable for the vehicles. It is the responsibility of vehicle owners to ensure that their vehicle headlamps are properly aligned after replacing the bulbs so as not to cause glare and distraction to other road users; and that such bulbs do not exceed the wattage rating recommended by the vehicle manufacturer.  Source:LTA

content_question: Are alloy rims allowed for commercial vehicles?
meta_description: Yes, we allow alloy rims that are originally factory-fitted to the vehicle and come with a certification from the vehic... read more answers
content_answer: Yes, we allow alloy rims that are originally factory-fitted to the vehicle and come with a certification from the vehicle manufacturer. These alloy rims have undergone testing by the vehicle manufacturer and have shown to comply with internationally recognised standards.   We also allow retrofitting of after-market alloy rims on in-use light commercial vehicles with a Maximum Laden Weight (MLW) of not more than 3,500 kg (e.g. vans, pickups, small buses and lorries) so long as it does not adversely affect the safe operation of the vehicles.  The rims and tyres fitted onto theses vehicles must be of the correct width, diameter and profile as recommended and certified safe for road use by the rim manufacturer.  This is because, if the rims and tyres used do not follow the recommended specifications, vehicle performance may be affected. As a result, road safety would be compromised. The alloy rims must be tested by the rim manufacturer to show compliance with internationally recognised standards that they would not adversely affect the performance and safe operation of the vehicles.  Source:LTA

content_question: Are passengers allowed in the cargo deck/compartment of light goods van?
meta_description: Goods vehicles should be used primarily for the carriage of goods. To help manage business costs, the Road Traffic Act ... read more answers
content_answer: Goods vehicles should be used primarily for the carriage of goods. To help manage business costs, the Road Traffic Act provides an exception for owners and hirers of goods vehicles, including goods vans, to use their vehicles to transport their workers to and from their places of work or business so long as they comply with various safety requirements.   Goods vans are generally not used for the mass transport of workers for commute trips and are observed to be used more by the specialist trade for the transport of goods or equipment as well as some attendants. We recognise that there could be some occasions where the owner or hirer of the goods van needs to use his van to transport his workers. As part of the safety requirement, the owner or hirer of the goods van must display a Maximum Passenger Capacity (MPC) label on the vehicle indicating the maximum number of workers that can be transported on the cargo deck of the vehicle. The MPC label serves as a reminder to the vehicle owner, hirer and driver of the maximum number of workers that the vehicle can carry on the cargo deck of the vehicle as well as facilitates enforcement against errant employers. When determining the maximum passenger capacity of a cargo deck, the usable deck area should not include the area occupied by any permanent fixtures on the cargo deck such as cranes, toolboxes, etc. If goods are also transported, the number of persons should be reduced accordingly. The MPC is calculated based on the total unoccupied deck area divided by the area of 0.372 square metres (4 square feet) per person, round down to the nearest whole number. The vehicle is not allowed to exceed its loading capacity or travel faster than the vehicle speed limit of 60 km/h or the stipulated road speed limit. Owner or hirer of goods van should also ensure that the van is fitted with proper air-conditioning or mechanical ventilation system so as to provide adequate comfort for the workers transported. The onus would be on the owner/driver to ensure the safety and welfare of the workers transported.  Source:LTA

content_question: Are there any guidelines on pasting sticker advertisements on private cars?
meta_description: LTA has no objection to the display of sticker advertisements or decals on vehicles so long as the following requiremen... read more answers
content_answer: LTA has no objection to the display of sticker advertisements or decals on vehicles so long as the following requirements are complied with: a)    no part of the stickers shall obstruct the view of the driver or pose any danger to other road users; b)    the stickers do not cover or mask any lighting systems, number plates, windows, windscreens, and other pre-requisite markings/labels on the vehicle (e.g. speed limit, maximum passenger capacity, company information for goods vehicles  etc); c)    graphics and/or words shall not appear in any way pornographic, obscene or vulgar. They must also not be seditious or affront any religious belief; d)    the basic colour of the vehicle must be maintained; e)    if the stickers are intended to be pasted across the windscreens and windows, they must not be more than 150mm (6 inches) measured from the top edge of the front windscreen and not more than 100mm (4 inches) measured from the top edge of the rear windscreen and side windows; and  f)     the resultant light transmittance for remaining areas of the front windscreen and both front windows must be at least 70%; and the rear windscreen and rear passenger windows must be at least 25%.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can an auto driven car be converted to a manual driven car?
meta_description: LTA allows the transmissions to be changed from auto to manual and vice versa. LTA requires the following to be submitt... read more answers
content_answer: LTA allows the transmissions to be changed from auto to manual and vice versa. LTA requires the following to be submitted for approval evaluation: a) Invoice of the proposed transmission from the supplier; and b) Certification from the manufacturer stating that the transmission is suitable for the vehicle.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I carry objects that are longer than the length of my lorry?
meta_description: The load carried by a motor vehicle shall not project beyond the body of the vehicle in such a manner or position as to... read more answers
content_answer: The load carried by a motor vehicle shall not project beyond the body of the vehicle in such a manner or position as to cause or be likely to cause danger to any person on a road. It shall be carried in such position where it is not likely to strike any person with whom the vehicle may collide or is not liable to cause injury to any person by reason of any projection thereon. Whenever a load that is being transported on a vehicle projects laterally beyond the body or wheels of the vehicle or any authorised fitting permanently attached to the vehicle, a red flag by day and a red lamp by night shall be affixed to the extreme lateral projection (if any) and the extreme rear end of such load so as to be clearly visible and give adequate warning to other road users.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I change my motorcycle's fuel tank to a bigger capacity?
meta_description: In general, any alternations carried out on a vehicle may adversely affect the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s safety and its operation. Prio... read more answers
content_answer: In general, any alternations carried out on a vehicle may adversely affect the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s safety and its operation. Prior to any conversion, vehicle owners are required to submit an application to the Vehicle Engineering Division of Land Transport Authority for the change. The application must include relevant installation details and supporting certification from the vehicle manufacturer stating that the fuel tank replacement will not adversely affect the design and construction of the vehicle.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I change the side mirror of a different model for my car?
meta_description: LTA does not engage in the type-approval of motor vehicle accessories.  We will however be concerned if the fitting of ... read more answers
content_answer: LTA does not engage in the type-approval of motor vehicle accessories.  We will however be concerned if the fitting of accessories adversely affect the safety and emission characteristics of the vehicle.  All vehicle mirrors, factory-fitted or after-market, installed in a vehicle must be of a design certified to be suitable for the vehicle by the vehicle/product manufacturer and be properly installed according to the manufacturer's recommendations. The mirrors must meet international standards such as those adopted in the European Union countries, Japan and the United States.  To enable LTA to advise you more specifically, we would appreciate it if you could provide us with the following: a) vehicle registration number of your vehicle; b) technical specifications and installation details (including pictures/drawings) of the aftermarket side mirror; c) certification from the manufacturer that the aftermarket side mirror is suitable to be fitted to the vehicle and would not adversely affect the safe operation of the vehicle; and d) evidence or test reports to show that the after-market side mirror has been manufactured and tested according to international recognised standards.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I install a LED Message Display (e.g. Thank you, Sorry etc) at rear of my vehicle wind screen?
meta_description: We do not allow the installation of additional or decorative vehicle lighting (both exterior and interior) as they coul... read more answers
content_answer: We do not allow the installation of additional or decorative vehicle lighting (both exterior and interior) as they could cause distraction or confusion to the vehicle driver and/or to other road users. As a result, road safety would be compromised.    Source:LTA

content_question: Can I fit additional lights on the door handle?
meta_description: We do not allow the installation of additional or decorative vehicle lighting (both exterior and interior) as they coul... read more answers
content_answer: We do not allow the installation of additional or decorative vehicle lighting (both exterior and interior) as they could cause to distract or confuse the vehicle driver and/or other road users. As a result, road safety would be compromised.   Source:LTA

content_question: Can I install curtains in my vehicle?
meta_description: Curtains can be fitted on the passenger windows of a vehicle as long as the curtains are not drawn while the vehicle is... read more answers
content_answer: Curtains can be fitted on the passenger windows of a vehicle as long as the curtains are not drawn while the vehicle is in motion and/or obstruct the view of the driver.  Source:LTA

content_question: Do I need to seek LTA's approval if I wish to replace the engine of my vehicle? What is the procedure to do so?
meta_description: LTA allows changing of engines provided that the replacement engine is of the same type as the original one.   Source:LTA
content_answer: LTA allows changing of engines provided that the replacement engine is of the same type as the original one.   Source:LTA

content_question: Is LTA\xe2\x80\x99s approval required for the installation of a in-car camera?
meta_description: No. We do not engage in the type approval of motor vehicle accessories such as in-car cameras. We also do not accredit ... read more answers
content_answer: No. We do not engage in the type approval of motor vehicle accessories such as in-car cameras. We also do not accredit or appoint motor vehicle workshops to carry out such installation works. Vehicle owners who wish to install and use any of such in-car cameras are advised to ensure that the cameras system would not adversely affect the safe operation of vehicles, nor obstruct the driver's vision. The installation of such system must be carried out in accordance with the product manufacturer's recommendations with sound engineering practice (e.g. securely mounted). It is the vehicle owner's responsibility to ensure that such system does not operate or used such that it results in violation or intrusion of other person\xe2\x80\x99s privacy.  Source:LTA

content_question: Is pasting full chrome stickers on a car allowed by the LTA?
meta_description: Due to the highly reflective nature of chrome surfaces, the LTA does not allow the body of any motor vehicle to be chro... read more answers
content_answer: Due to the highly reflective nature of chrome surfaces, the LTA does not allow the body of any motor vehicle to be chromed as it would cause glare and distraction to other road users and as a result, road safety would be compromised.   Source:LTA

content_question: Is there a list of approved headlamp aftermarket replacement bulbs for private cars?
meta_description: We require all designs of vehicle lamps to comply with the Road Traffic (Motor Vehicles, Construction & Use) Rules and ... read more answers
content_answer: We require all designs of vehicle lamps to comply with the Road Traffic (Motor Vehicles, Construction & Use) Rules and Road Traffic (Motor Vehicles, Lightings) Rules. They must bear approved markings to show that they comply with internationally recognised standards, such as those adopted in the European Union countries, Japan and the United States. In addition, the lights emitted from the lamps must also conform to the intended illuminated colour and intensity. We have been approached by Philips and Osram to evaluate some of their bulbs for use on vehicles. To date, we have no objection to the use of Philips Blue Vision, Philips Blue Vision Ultra, Philips Xtreme Vision, Philips Silver Vision, Philips Vision Plus, Osram Silverstar and Osram Cool Blue bulbs as these models comply with the relevant ECE regulation and bear the ECE markings.  Source:LTA

content_question: Do I need to inform LTA if my car suddenly stalled on the first lane of the expressway and caused me to stop there for 3 minutes, or will I be fined for stopping on the expressway?
meta_description: No , you do not need to inform the LTA as there was no accident involved. However if you wnt to be safe, just drop them... read more answers
content_answer: No , you do not need to inform the LTA as there was no accident involved. However if you wnt to be safe, just drop them an email to explain. More importantly, if your car suddenly stalls, get it checked.

content_question: Where to find the cheapest petrol in Singapore?
meta_description: Every gas station has different promotions daily/weekly, some have joint discounts with different credit card companies... read more answers
content_answer: Every gas station has different promotions daily/weekly, some have joint discounts with different credit card companies so it varies from company to company. One thing for sure is that once you find the ideal company, try to always pump with the same company to make sure your car is getting the same treatment and not all over the place.

content_question: What is CNG?
meta_description: CNG stands for compressed natural gas. Natural gas is predominantly methane and is used by many people for cooking and ... read more answers
content_answer: CNG stands for compressed natural gas. Natural gas is predominantly methane and is used by many people for cooking and heating in their homes. Like petrol and diesel it is a fossil fuel but burns much cleaner. The result of this is greatly reduced vehicle emissions.

content_question: Between CNG, petrol and diesel, which is the best option for a vehicle?
meta_description: In the long run CNG is cheaper due to its lower cost. It is cheaper than both diesel and petrol
content_answer: In the long run CNG is cheaper due to its lower cost. It is cheaper than both diesel and petrol

content_question: Can a P-plate driver become a Private Hire Vehicle (PHV) driver?
meta_description: No, to become a PHV driver , you need to have at least 2 years of driving experience.
content_answer: No, to become a PHV driver , you need to have at least 2 years of driving experience.

content_question: In Singapore, is it cheaper to rent a car or buy a car?
meta_description: It is no secret that in the long run it is cheaper to buy and own a car. However, the hefty upfront payments, the hassl... read more answers
content_answer: It is no secret that in the long run it is cheaper to buy and own a car. However, the hefty upfront payments, the hassle of managing car ownership and the threat of high premiums after car accidents may tip the balance in favour of renting. The bonus of changing a new car every 2 \xe2\x80\x93 3 years without increasing TDSR makes renting a car a very attractive option.  So it depends on your individual needs and preferences on how often you would like to change vehicle.

content_question: Can I convert a normal plate to an OPC or ROPC plate?
meta_description: Yes you are able to convert a normal plate vehicle to a OPC or ROPC plate
content_answer: Yes you are able to convert a normal plate vehicle to a OPC or ROPC plate

content_question: Weekend car COE expiring Jun 2018. To consider coe renewal or get new car on weekend scheme?
meta_description: There are a few pointers to consider and each has its own perks and drawbacks. Here is an article that might help you i... read more answers
content_answer: There are a few pointers to consider and each has its own perks and drawbacks. Here is an article that might help you in your decision!   http://www.motorist.sg/article/120/renew-coe-vs-buying-a-car-which-is-really-better-for-you

content_question: What is the difference between the previous mirror requirements and the new mirror requirements for such HGVs and buses?
meta_description: Previously, all HGVs and buses are required to be equipped with at least two mirrors to allow drivers to view both side... read more answers
content_answer: Previously, all HGVs and buses are required to be equipped with at least two mirrors to allow drivers to view both sides rearwards of the vehicle. The new mirror requirements involve installing additional mirrors to cover blind spots located at the immediate left side and front of the vehicle. Drivers will be able to better spot pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and other motorists who are in these blind spot areas and reduce the risk of accidents.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why is LTA imposing the additional mirror requirements on Heavy Goods Vehicles (HGVs) with Maximum Laden Weight (MLW) exceeding 12,000 kg and buses with MLW exceeding 8,000 kg, and not other HGVs and buses?
meta_description: HGVs and buses with lower MLW typically have lower windscreens and window sills, and thus generally do not have the bli... read more answers
content_answer: HGVs and buses with lower MLW typically have lower windscreens and window sills, and thus generally do not have the blind spots that are present in larger HGVs and buses. Owners of these HGVs and buses with lower MLW can nevertheless choose to fit additional blind-spot mirrors on their vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will LTA allow the vehicle owner to fit cameras instead of blind-spot mirrors?
meta_description: Vehicle owners may choose to fit a conventional mirror, camera-monitor or other device able to present visual informati... read more answers
content_answer: Vehicle owners may choose to fit a conventional mirror, camera-monitor or other device able to present visual information of objects in the blind spot to the driver. If the vehicle owner decides to install cameras to cover the blind spot areas, the owner must ensure that the camera system would not adversely affect the safe operation of the vehicles nor obstruct the view of the driver. The installation of the camera system has to be carried out in accordance with the product manufacturer's recommendation and with sound engineering practice. The camera system will be inspected at the authorised vehicle inspection centres during the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s periodic inspection.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will the mirrors be checked at every periodic inspection? What is the frequency of periodic inspection for HGVs and buses?
meta_description: The mirrors of HGVs and heavy buses will be checked at every periodic inspection to ensure the mirrors/Fresnel lens and... read more answers
content_answer: The mirrors of HGVs and heavy buses will be checked at every periodic inspection to ensure the mirrors/Fresnel lens and/or other visual devices have been installed and properly maintained. HGVs and buses are subjected to yearly inspections if they are below 10 years of age, and 6-monthly inspections if they are more than 10 years old.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can a registered owner of a petrol-CNG vehicle send his vehicle to a workshop who is not a CNG system supplier/installer to remove the CNG system?
meta_description: No. A workshop who is not a CNG system supplier/installer would not have the proprietary knowledge to ensure the CNG sy... read more answers
content_answer: No. A workshop who is not a CNG system supplier/installer would not have the proprietary knowledge to ensure the CNG system is properly removed. Due to the high operating pressure of the CNG system, in particular the CNG cylinders, it is important that removal of CNG systems on vehicles must be performed by qualified technicians trained by the CNG system suppliers.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I install CNG conversion kit in a neighbouring country?
meta_description: We do not allow the conversion of vehicles to run on CNG to be carried out overseas, e.g. in Malaysia, because we do no... read more answers
content_answer: We do not allow the conversion of vehicles to run on CNG to be carried out overseas, e.g. in Malaysia, because we do not have information or control on the safety standards that overseas CNG system installers practice or adopt for CNG system installations.  We also recognise that it is not convenient for owners of CNG vehicles to receive technical support from overseas CNG installers.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I transfer the CNG kit to another vehicle?
meta_description: LTA will consider the transfer of CNG kit only if it is duly certified and tested by the CNG kit manufacturer that the ... read more answers
content_answer: LTA will consider the transfer of CNG kit only if it is duly certified and tested by the CNG kit manufacturer that the used CNG kit is in good working condition and continues to comply with the relevant standards. However, the used CNG cylinder cannot be reused.    Source: LTA

content_question: How can I find out on the possible performance of my car if it runs on CNG?
meta_description: Prior to the installation of the CNG systems, vehicle owners are advised to check with their CNG system installers to f... read more answers
content_answer: Prior to the installation of the CNG systems, vehicle owners are advised to check with their CNG system installers to first assess whether a specific vehicle model/type is suitable for installation of a CNG system. The CNG system installers are to educate their customers on the expected performance of the CNG vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: How do I know when my CNG cylinder expires?
meta_description: You may wish to approach your vehicle agent or the CNG system specialist to check the expiry date of CNG cylinders.  Source: LTA
content_answer: You may wish to approach your vehicle agent or the CNG system specialist to check the expiry date of CNG cylinders.  Source: LTA

content_question: How does a registered owner apply to convert his/her petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle?
meta_description: The procedures to convert a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle are as follows: 1.\tOwner to complete and submit App... read more answers
content_answer: The procedures to convert a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle are as follows: 1.\tOwner to complete and submit Application Form R18 \xe2\x80\x93 Application for Removal of CNG System from Vehicle, (downloadable at www.onemotoring.com.sg (LTA Information & Guidelines > Forms Download) to the Vehicle Approval & Control Division (VACD), Counter 28, Level 2, LTA Customer Service Centre, 10 Sin Ming Drive, Singapore 575701, for evaluation and endorsement;  2.\tUpon endorsement by VACD, owner to proceed to Vehicle Registration & Licensing Service Operations Division, Multi-Transactions counter, to make payment for the Green Vehicle Rebate (GVR) top-up and administrative fee of $21.40 (inclusive of GST). (Please click here to check the GVR top-up amount);  3.\tUpon payment, a notification letter on the successful amendment of the vehicle specifications will be issued to the owner. Owner must remove the CNG system and pass a vehicle inspection within 10 calendar days;  4.\tOwner is to contact the CNG system supplier/installer to arrange for the removal of the CNG system from the vehicle. Owner or the CNG System supplier/installer will need to submit the following information electronically through LTA\xe2\x80\x99s Vehicle Inspection and Type Approval System (VITAS) under the \xe2\x80\x9cChange of Vehicle Particulars Inspection (with VACD Approval)\xe2\x80\x9d and pay a processing fee of $64.20 (inclusive of GST):  a.\ta completed Change of Vehicle Particular application form by the owner to remove the CNG system. The form can be downloaded from our VITAS website at http://www.vicom.com.sg/Portals/0/After-market%20exhaust%20Checklist.pdf;  b.\tcertification from the CNG system supplier that the CNG system has been removed according to the product manufacturer\xe2\x80\x99s recommendation with sound engineering practice and does not adversely affect the safe operation and/or exhaust emissions characteristics of the vehicle and affected parts on the vehicle (e.g. intake manifold, drilled boot space, etc) have been restored to its original condition; c.\tcertification from the CNG system supplier that the used CNG system has been properly disposed of; d.\tinvoice for the works; and e.\tthe notification letter issued by LTA on the successful amendment of the vehicle specifications.  5.\tUpon receiving the approval from VITAS, owner is to send the vehicle for inspection at any Authorised Vehicle Inspection Centre (AIC). AIC will issue an acknowledgement letter when the vehicle passes the inspection. Please note that an inspection fee will be payable to the AIC.  Source: LTA

content_question: How does LTA compute the Green Vehicle Rebate (GVR) top-up amount?
meta_description: The calculation is based on the number of months and days the vehicle is registered as a green vehicle and an amortizat... read more answers
content_answer: The calculation is based on the number of months and days the vehicle is registered as a green vehicle and an amortization period of 10 years (for cars) and 8 years (for taxis).   The formula used is as follows:-   For Cars GVR Top-Up = GVR received / 120 months x (120 months - no. of months & days registered as a green vehicle at time of conversion to normal petrol car)   For Taxis GVR Top-Up = GVR received / 96 months x (96 months - no. of months & days registered as a green vehicle at time of conversion to normal petrol taxi)  Source: LTA

content_question: How is the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s PARF benefit affected with the conversion from a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle?
meta_description: If the registered owner had paid the GVR top-up amount at the point of converting from a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol... read more answers
content_answer: If the registered owner had paid the GVR top-up amount at the point of converting from a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle, any PARF and COE rebates to be granted to the last registered owner at de-registration would be based on the actual amount of ARF and Quota Premium (COE) paid, including any top-up amount.  Source: LTA

content_question: Is it an offence for not displaying CNG marking on my CNG vehicle?
meta_description: Every CNG vehicle is required to carry a 'CNG' marking affixed to its front bumper and rear bumper or boot respectively... read more answers
content_answer: Every CNG vehicle is required to carry a 'CNG' marking affixed to its front bumper and rear bumper or boot respectively. The 'CNG' markings enable the SCDF officers to identify CNG vehicles readily. It is important for SCDF officers to adopt appropriate extrication procedures in emergency situations such as road accidents involving CNG vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: Is the CNG cylinder safe to be installed in a vehicle?
meta_description: The CNG cylinders provided by all the LTA approved CNG system suppliers and the installation of such cylinders on vehic... read more answers
content_answer: The CNG cylinders provided by all the LTA approved CNG system suppliers and the installation of such cylinders on vehicles have to be certified to comply with internationally recognized standards for CNG vehicles, e.g. UNECE R110. The installation of CNG systems on vehicles must be performed by qualified installers appointed and trained by the CNG system suppliers.  Source: LTA

content_question: What does a registered owner have to pay to convert his/her petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle by removing the CNG system?
meta_description: To convert a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle, the registered owner is required to pay the following to the LTA:... read more answers
content_answer: To convert a petrol-CNG vehicle to a petrol vehicle, the registered owner is required to pay the following to the LTA:   a. the un-used portion of the Green Vehicle Rebate (GVR) (if applicable); b. an administrative fee of $21.40 (inclusive of GST); and c. a Vehicle Inspection and Type Approval System (VITAS) processing fee of $64.20 (inclusive of GST) for the \xe2\x80\x9cChange of Vehicle Particulars\xe2\x80\x9d inspection.   The registered owner may refer to the e-Services at http://www.onemotoring.com.sg (LTA e-Services > Enquire Green Vehicle Rebate Top-up Amount) for the GVR top-up amount for his/her vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: What is the purpose of subjecting CNG-driven vehicles to the additional inspection requirements during the periodic vehicle inspections?
meta_description: Due to the high operating pressure of the CNG system, in particular the CNG cylinders, it is important to have addition... read more answers
content_answer: Due to the high operating pressure of the CNG system, in particular the CNG cylinders, it is important to have additional inspection requirements during the periodic inspections to ensure that the CNG system is maintained in a good operating condition and safeguard the interest of all who may come in contact with the CNG system, particularly the occupants of CNG-driven vehicles and other road users.  Source: LTA

content_question: What will happen if my vehicle fails the additional inspection items at the periodic inspection?
meta_description: If the failed items are CNG system-related, you will have to send the vehicle to your CNG system installer for rectific... read more answers
content_answer: If the failed items are CNG system-related, you will have to send the vehicle to your CNG system installer for rectification and then produce the vehicle for re-inspection at any of the LTA-authorised vehicle inspection centres. The vehicle is required to pass the re-inspection.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where are the CNG stations located?
meta_description: 1.\tSMART Energy 1 Mandai Link Singapore 728650  2.\tSMART Energy 9A Serangoon North Avenue 5 Singapore 554500  3... read more answers
content_answer: 1.\tSMART Energy 1 Mandai Link Singapore 728650  2.\tSMART Energy 9A Serangoon North Avenue 5 Singapore 554500  3.\tUNION Energy 50 Old Toh Tuck Road Singapore 597657  Source: LTA

content_question: Where can a registered owner of a petrol-CNG vehicle check if he/she is required to make a Green Vehicle Rebate (GVR) top-up when he/she removes the CNG tank from the vehicle?
meta_description: Only owners who had enjoyed GVR at the point of registration of a petrol-CNG vehicle will need to top up the GVR on rem... read more answers
content_answer: Only owners who had enjoyed GVR at the point of registration of a petrol-CNG vehicle will need to top up the GVR on removal of the CNG system. Registered owner may refer to the e-Services at http://www.onemotoring.com.sg (LTA e-Services > Enquire Green Vehicle Rebate Top-up Amount) for the GVR top-up amount for the vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where can I purchase the CNG identification marking?
meta_description: The CNG identification marking can be purchased from any LTA approved CNG system suppliers or their respective appointe... read more answers
content_answer: The CNG identification marking can be purchased from any LTA approved CNG system suppliers or their respective appointed installers.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where do I get the CNG system information marking if my vehicle does not have one?
meta_description: You can approach any of the LTA approved CNG system suppliers or their respective appointed installers who have install... read more answers
content_answer: You can approach any of the LTA approved CNG system suppliers or their respective appointed installers who have installed the CNG system onto your vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will my vehicle's warranty void after converting to CNG-driven vehicle?
meta_description: You would have to check with your vehicle dealers and the insurance company which you have purchased your vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s ins... read more answers
content_answer: You would have to check with your vehicle dealers and the insurance company which you have purchased your vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s insurance before you proceed with the conversion.  There will be an additional inspection fee of not more than $15.00. Since the inspection fees have been de-regulated since 1997, the vehicle inspection centres will be accountable on the amount of additional inspection fee charge for every CNG system inspection. This fee is not regulated and determined by LTA. For more details of the additional inspection fee, please check with the respective inspection centre.  Vehicle inspection centres impose the fee as they are given additional responsibility to perform the additional checks. This entails the deployment of resources and purchase of equipment.  Source: LTA

content_question: How much will the enhanced rear and side marking requirements cost the owners of existing and new long vehicles?
meta_description: The cost of the enhanced rear and side markings is determined by the suppliers on a commercial basis. We understand tha... read more answers
content_answer: The cost of the enhanced rear and side markings is determined by the suppliers on a commercial basis. We understand that it costs about $40, excluding installation charges  Source:LTA

content_question: What are the enhanced rear and side marking requirements for long vehicles? Do these requirements apply only to new vehicles or will the markings on existing vehicles have to be changed?
meta_description: The enhanced requirements will apply to both new and existing vehicles. The changes are:  \xe2\x80\xa2\tDurable rear and side mar... read more answers
content_answer: The enhanced requirements will apply to both new and existing vehicles. The changes are:  \xe2\x80\xa2\tDurable rear and side markings with higher retro-reflective properties will be used; i.e. the new markings will have to comply with the UN ECE Regulation Number 104 instead of the current BS.AU 152:1970 standard; \xe2\x80\xa2\tThe colour of rear and side markings will be red and yellow respectively, instead of the existing chevron colour scheme of alternating red and yellow stripes for both markings; and \xe2\x80\xa2\tLong vehicles will now have three side markings (instead of one side marking currently required for trailers) fitted on each side of the vehicle / trailer.  In addition, the following requirements are no longer necessary:  \xe2\x80\xa2\tThe "Long Vehicle" sign, currently required for goods vehicles and trailers with overall length exceeding 13 metres; and \xe2\x80\xa2\tFlank lights for trailers used as the increase in the number of side markings as well as the higher retro-reflective properties of the markings are sufficient.   Source;LTA

content_question: What are the penalties if owners of long vehicles do not install the enhanced markings by the respective implementation date?
meta_description: Vehicle owners who fail to install the enhanced markings by the implementation date are liable to a fine of up to $1,00... read more answers
content_answer: Vehicle owners who fail to install the enhanced markings by the implementation date are liable to a fine of up to $1,000 or a jail term of up to three months for the first offence. Repeat offenders are liable to a fine of up to $2,000 or a jail term of up to six months.  Source: LTA

content_question: What type of long vehicles will be affected by the enhanced rear and side marking requirements?
meta_description: Affected vehicles include goods vehicles that are more than 10 metres and trailers that are more than 5 metres. New and... read more answers
content_answer: Affected vehicles include goods vehicles that are more than 10 metres and trailers that are more than 5 metres. New and existing mobile cranes that exceed 10 metres in length are also required to fit rear markings.  Source:LTA

content_question: When were the enhanced rear and side marking requirements for long vehicles implemented?
meta_description: The enhanced requirements were implemented for all long vehicles registered on and after 1 August 2005.  Owners of lo... read more answers
content_answer: The enhanced requirements were implemented for all long vehicles registered on and after 1 August 2005.  Owners of long vehicles registered before 1 August 2005 were given up to 31 July 2007 to comply with the enhanced requirements.  Source:LTA

content_question: Where can vehicle owners go to purchase the enhanced rear and side marking for long vehicles?
meta_description: The new markings can be bought from most vehicle accessory shops, builders of trailers, and motor workshops that servic... read more answers
content_answer: The new markings can be bought from most vehicle accessory shops, builders of trailers, and motor workshops that service or repair heavy vehicles.  Source:LTA

content_question: Why is there a need for the rear and side marking requirements to be enhanced? And why now?
meta_description: LTA takes a serious view of the safety of road users. Rules and regulations are constantly reviewed to ensure this. Thi... read more answers
content_answer: LTA takes a serious view of the safety of road users. Rules and regulations are constantly reviewed to ensure this. This latest review is in response to the improvements in the materials used for such markings and the increasing use of such improved markings world-wide to make long vehicles more prominent to other motorists on the roads. This will in turn improve road safety in Singapore.  Source;LTA

content_question: Can I install fog lamps on my vehicle?
meta_description: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) allows the installation of fog lamps on vehicles as long as the fog lamps comply wit... read more answers
content_answer: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) allows the installation of fog lamps on vehicles as long as the fog lamps comply with the requisite safety standards. Such lamps can only be used in adverse weather conditions where there is reduced visibility, such as during heavy downpours or in hazy conditions.   Source: LTA

content_question: How do I know if the fog lamps installed on my vehicle comply with LTA's requirements?
meta_description: Front and rear fog lamps that meet the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Regulations bear 'B' and '... read more answers
content_answer: Front and rear fog lamps that meet the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Regulations bear 'B' and 'F' markings respectively. If the fog lamps on your vehicle bear such markings, they would have complied with the relevant UNECE Regulations.   If there are no markings on your fog lamps and you are not sure if they have met LTA's requirements, check with the vehicle's importer or motor agent to see if the fog lamps are originally fitted or approved by the LTA.  Source:LTA

content_question: How would I know that I have turned on the fog lamp?
meta_description: Cars with factory-fitted fog lamps have an indicator on the instrument panel or a light emitted on the switch as tell-t... read more answers
content_answer: Cars with factory-fitted fog lamps have an indicator on the instrument panel or a light emitted on the switch as tell-tale signs that the fog lamp is switched on. Motorists can refer to their vehicle manual to find out how to identify whether their fog lamps have been switched on.  Source:LTA

content_question: Is it an offence to turn on the fog lamps when driving at night?
meta_description: Under normal weather conditions, be it in the day or at night, there is no need to switch on the fog lamps. This is bec... read more answers
content_answer: Under normal weather conditions, be it in the day or at night, there is no need to switch on the fog lamps. This is because the light emitted from vehicle headlamps is sufficient to illuminate the road ahead. Switching on front fog lamps will not further improve forward vision under clear weather conditions. Some drivers have provided feedback that front fog lamps, when switched on indiscriminately, are intimidating and cause added stress to the driver in front. Switching on rear fog lamps unnecessarily may also cause confusion to motorists travelling behind you as the intense red light emitted could be mistaken as the brake light. Motorists who abuse the use of fog lamps are liable, upon conviction, to a fine of up to $1,000 or a jail term of up to three months for first offence. Repeat offenders are liable, upon conviction, to a fine of up to $2,000 or a jail term of up to six months.  Source:LTA

content_question: What are the penalties if motorists abuse the use of fog lamps?
meta_description: Motorists who abuse the use of fog lamps are liable, upon conviction, to a fine of up to $1,000 or a jail term of up to... read more answers
content_answer: Motorists who abuse the use of fog lamps are liable, upon conviction, to a fine of up to $1,000 or a jail term of up to three months for first offence. Repeat offenders are liable, upon conviction, to a fine of up to $2,000 or a jail term of up to six months.  Source:LTA

content_question: What are the requirements for installing aftermarket fog lamps?
meta_description: The following requirements must be met when installing aftermarket fog lamps:   (a) The fog lamps should bear approve... read more answers
content_answer: The following requirements must be met when installing aftermarket fog lamps:   (a) The fog lamps should bear approved markings to show that they have met international recognised standards such as those adopted in the countries of the European Union, Japan and the United States. For example, if the fog lamps meet United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Regulations, they will bear markings 'B' and 'F' for the front and rear fog lamps respectively.   (b) The front fog lamps must cast a white or yellow light. They must be installed not more than 400 mm from the sides of the vehicle and at least 600 mm apart from each other. They should also be located below the headlights and at least 250 mm above the road surface.  (c) The rear fog lamp mounted on a vehicle can be a single unit or a matched pair. The rear fog lamp must cast a red light and be located between 250 mm and 1,000 mm above the road surface. For a single rear fog lamp, it must be installed at the centre or offside of the vehicle. In all cases, the distance between the rear fog lamp and each stop lamp must be greater than 100 mm.  (d) The front fog lamps can only be switched on if the front and rear position lamps are switched on. The rear fog lamps can only be switched on when the front headlamps are switched on.  (e) There should be separate switches for switching the headlamps and fog lamps on. The switches must be constructed such that switching on the position lamps or headlamps do not automatically switch on the fog lamps.  Source:LTA

content_question: What should I do if my fog lamps are not approved by LTA?
meta_description: If your fog lamps are not approved by LTA, please cover them at all times when the vehicle is used in Singapore.  Source:LTA
content_answer: If your fog lamps are not approved by LTA, please cover them at all times when the vehicle is used in Singapore.  Source:LTA

content_question: Why is the use of fog lamps allowed only during adverse weather conditions?
meta_description: Under normal weather conditions, be it in the day or at night, there is no need to switch on the fog lamps. This is bec... read more answers
content_answer: Under normal weather conditions, be it in the day or at night, there is no need to switch on the fog lamps. This is because the light emitted from vehicle headlamps is sufficient to illuminate the road ahead. Switching on front fog lamps will not further improve forward vision under clear weather conditions. Some drivers have provided feedback that front fog lamps, when switched on indiscriminately, are intimidating and cause added stress to the driver in front. Switching on rear fog lamps unnecessarily may also cause confusion to motorists travelling behind you as the intense red light emitted could be mistaken as the brake light.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I retrofit my halogen headlamps with an after-market HID headlamp system such as Xenon lights?
meta_description: In general,we do not allow the retrofitting of HID lamp systems on existing vehicles, unless it is duly certified by th... read more answers
content_answer: In general,we do not allow the retrofitting of HID lamp systems on existing vehicles, unless it is duly certified by the vehicle manufacturers.   This is because converting the existing headlamps to HID headlamps would require the entire headlamp assembly, including the electrical system, to be replaced as the reflectors and lenses are different from those in a conventional halogen headlamp.  In addition, the wiring of the existing headlamp system would not be able to handle the much higher starting current required for a HID headlamp system. This could cause extensive damage to the headlamp assembly and electrical system and therefore could pose a fire hazard to road users.  Source:LTA

content_question: Does the new requirement to HID Lamps only apply to new vehicles or will all existing vehicles be affected?
meta_description: The new requirement will take effect from 1 January 2010 and will apply only to newly registered vehicles fitted with H... read more answers
content_answer: The new requirement will take effect from 1 January 2010 and will apply only to newly registered vehicles fitted with HID headlamps. It will not be applied retrospectively to in-use vehicles with HID headlamps as otherwise, extensive modifications must be made to the vehicle's headlamp system.  Source:LTA

content_question: What are the cost implications to new vehicle owners for HID Lamps Installation?
meta_description: According to some motor agents, as more vehicle models are now fitted with HID headlamps equipped with the auto-levelli... read more answers
content_answer: According to some motor agents, as more vehicle models are now fitted with HID headlamps equipped with the auto-levelling feature, the incremental cost for the added feature is negligible due to economies of scale.  Source:LTA

content_question: What can I do to avoid glare from misaligned vehicle headlamps?
meta_description: The following are some tips on how to cope with glare from misaligned vehicle headlamps (applicable to right-hand drive... read more answers
content_answer: The following are some tips on how to cope with glare from misaligned vehicle headlamps (applicable to right-hand drive vehicles only):  a) If the headlights from oncoming vehicles are too bright, look straight ahead or slightly to the left. If you momentarily look, say, at the white line on the side of the road, you would still be able to see what you need to with your periphery vision.  b) Adjust your side mirrors properly to minimise glare from the vehicles behind you. Here's how: While sitting in the driver's seat, lean to the right and rest your head against the window; adjust the driver-side mirror so you can just see your rear fender. Next, lean to the left so your head is in the center of the vehicle; adjust the passenger-side mirror so the left rear fender is just visible.  c) Make sure all glasses on your vehicle (the headlights, windshield, windows and mirrors) are clean. Dirt diffuses light, thus creating glare.  Source:LTA

content_question: What is a HID headlamp system and how is this system different from normal halogen lamps?
meta_description: contain an inert gas (Xenon), which emits light when it comes in contact with a high-voltage electrical arc.  HID lam... read more answers
content_answer: contain an inert gas (Xenon), which emits light when it comes in contact with a high-voltage electrical arc.  HID lamps produce up to twice as much light as halogen lamps, with a bluish-white cast and minimal fading at the periphery of the beams. However, the brightness perceived by an individual depends on the distance from the light source, beam direction, relative brightness of the surrounding environment, and other factors.  Source:LTA

content_question: What is an auto-levelling feature and how does it work?
meta_description: The auto-levelling feature is a mechanism that automatically corrects the vertical deviation of light axis resulting fr... read more answers
content_answer: The auto-levelling feature is a mechanism that automatically corrects the vertical deviation of light axis resulting from changes in suspension due to weight and also under hard acceleration. This helps to relieve dazzle to oncoming vehicles. For example, if the vehicle is carrying more passengers or luggage and the rear is lower, the headlights would adjust downwards to reduce glare to oncoming traffic without compromising the improved visibility HID headlamps give to drivers. On the other hand, if the vehicle is carrying a lighter load and the rear is raised, the headlights would adjust upwards to illuminate the roads properly.  Source:LTA

content_question: What is the new technical requirement that LTA will be introducing for vehicles fitted with HID headlamps?
meta_description: With effect from 1 January 2010, LTA will require all newly registered vehicles fitted with HID headlamps to be equippe... read more answers
content_answer: With effect from 1 January 2010, LTA will require all newly registered vehicles fitted with HID headlamps to be equipped with an auto-levelling feature. However, as the application of HID technology on motorcycles is not mature, motorcycles will not be subject to the auto-levelling requirement.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are HID headlamps/whiter headlamp bulbs allowed for use on vehicles registered in Singapore since our streets are adequately lighted?
meta_description: LTA has allowed HID headlamps to be fitted on vehicles registered in Singapore as they meet the relevant safety standar... read more answers
content_answer: LTA has allowed HID headlamps to be fitted on vehicles registered in Singapore as they meet the relevant safety standards. In addition, HID headlamps are more energy efficient and can improve the visibility of drivers as compared with standard halogen lamps.  The use of HID headlamps/whiter headlamp bulbs is a technological trend in the automotive industry. Vehicle manufacturers are likely to produce more vehicles fitted with such headlamps/headlamp bulbs in the future. It is anticipated that by the year 2010, about 1 in 2 cars manufactured in Japan and Europe would be factory-fitted with HID headlamps.   Some motorists have given LTA feedback that HID headlamps and whiter headlamp bulbs are bright and glaring. We understand the concerns raised by motorists in Singapore, as they are not accustomed to the lighting. When the automotive industry switched from yellowish tungsten lighting to whiter halogen lighting in the 1970s, many motorists also had similar feedback about the brightness and glare caused by such lamps initially. However, motorists have grown accustomed to the use of halogen lighting over time. As with other lighting systems, the HID headlamp system or whiter headlamp bulbs will not cause unwanted glare or discomfort to other road users if they are properly aligned.  Source:LTA

content_question: Why has LTA given a 2-year lead time for the motor dealers to comply with the new requirement?
meta_description: The motor dealers have given LTA feedback that their principals/vehicle manufacturers require at least a two-year lead ... read more answers
content_answer: The motor dealers have given LTA feedback that their principals/vehicle manufacturers require at least a two-year lead time to comply with our new requirement. The lead time is necessary because the production schedule of vehicles meant for the Singapore market has been fixed for the next one to two years and it would not be possible to adjust the schedule to include the auto-levelling feature. LTA has taken this into consideration in its decision on the implementation date.  Source:LTA

content_question: Will HID lamps/white halogen lamps cause glare?
meta_description: As with other lighting systems, the HID lamp system or whiter headlamps bulbs will not cause unwanted glare or discomfo... read more answers
content_answer: As with other lighting systems, the HID lamp system or whiter headlamps bulbs will not cause unwanted glare or discomfort to other road users if they are properly aligned.  For many new vehicle makes and models with factory-fitted HID headlamp systems, vehicle manufacturers have incorporated an auto-levelling feature, which automatically adjusts the headlamp angle and direction based on road and driving conditions to minimise glare. Some vehicle manufacturers are also attempting to reduce glare by changing the constitution of the glass used in the vehicle's headlamp, windscreens, and windows.  Source:LTA

content_question: Can I install sliding windows or must it be fixed?
meta_description: The vehicle owner can decide whether the side window is fixed or sliding, as long as the safety requirements are met an... read more answers
content_answer: The vehicle owner can decide whether the side window is fixed or sliding, as long as the safety requirements are met and the windows installed safely.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I retain/install a rear partition to prevent goods from falling over to the front of the driver's cabin?
meta_description: Yes, however, the driver will have to ensure his own safety as well as the safety of his workers if he is transporting them.  Source: LTA
content_answer: Yes, however, the driver will have to ensure his own safety as well as the safety of his workers if he is transporting them.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I tint the window glasses and what is the light transmittance requirement for side windows?
meta_description: The resultant light transmittance of the side windows of the cargo compartment must be at least 25%. You may wish to re... read more answers
content_answer: The resultant light transmittance of the side windows of the cargo compartment must be at least 25%. You may wish to refer to the modification guidelines (https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/en/lta_information_guidelines/modifications_and_vehoffences/modification_guide.html) for more details.  Source: LTA

content_question: Do I have to apply to LTA for the installation of side windows or for the removal of the rear partition? Who should I engage to install side windows or remove the rear partition?
meta_description: You do not need to apply to LTA to install the side windows or to remove the rear partition. You could contact a motor ... read more answers
content_answer: You do not need to apply to LTA to install the side windows or to remove the rear partition. You could contact a motor agent or workshop for assistance.  Source: LTA

content_question: Do I need to send my goods vehicle for inspection after the installation of the side windows or the removal of the partition?
meta_description: You do not need to send your goods vehicle for inspection after the installation of the side windows or the removal of ... read more answers
content_answer: You do not need to send your goods vehicle for inspection after the installation of the side windows or the removal of partition.  Source: LTA

content_question: How do I ensure that the windows installed on my goods vehicle is of an approved type?
meta_description: Automotive glass that are tested and certified to meet international standards, such as those adopted in the European U... read more answers
content_answer: Automotive glass that are tested and certified to meet international standards, such as those adopted in the European Union countries and Japan, would bear approval markings. Examples of such standards are the European ECE Regulation 43 or Japan Safety Regulation (JSR) Article 29. You can conduct a visual check on the approval marking, which is commonly found on the lower left or right side of the window.  Source: LTA

content_question: How much does it cost to install the side windows or remove the rear partition?
meta_description: You would have to contact your vehicle dealer or any motor agent or workshop for information on the costs involved.  Source: LTA
content_answer: You would have to contact your vehicle dealer or any motor agent or workshop for information on the costs involved.  Source: LTA

content_question: My vehicle does not have a side window. Can I install one now?
meta_description: Owners or hirers of existing goods vans who wish to install side windows should ensure that the windows comply with int... read more answers
content_answer: Owners or hirers of existing goods vans who wish to install side windows should ensure that the windows comply with internationally recognised standards, such as the European ECE Regulation 43 or Japan Safety Regulation (JSR) Article 29. They should be installed safely.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the changes to the technical requirements for LGVs?
meta_description: Owners are now allowed to install windows at the rear cargo compartment of goods vans, as long as they comply with inte... read more answers
content_answer: Owners are now allowed to install windows at the rear cargo compartment of goods vans, as long as they comply with internationally recognised standards, such as the UNECE, DOT and JIS, and installed safely.   Owners of good vans are also allowed to remove the partition that separates the driver's cabin and the cargo compartment.   Source: LTA

content_question: What is the reason for making changes to the technical requirements for LGVs?
meta_description: With rapid advancements in automotive technology, the LTA regularly reviews the technical requirements that are imposed... read more answers
content_answer: With rapid advancements in automotive technology, the LTA regularly reviews the technical requirements that are imposed on vehicles, taking into account public feedback and suggestions. This is to ensure technical requirements are relevant and in-line with international practices. The rear side windows will enhance drivers' safety; drivers will be able to see better particularly when changing lanes, making turns or reversing into parking lots.   In addition, removing the partition will allow workers to escape through the front doors, in addition to the rear hatch door and side doors of the vehicle, in the event of an accident.   Source: LTA

content_question: Would my motor insurance premium be affected with the installation of side windows?
meta_description: You would have to check with your insurance company.  Source: LTA
content_answer: You would have to check with your insurance company.  Source: LTA

content_question: A worker sitting cross-legged on the carriage deck of a lorry may be uncomfortable. Can I allow my workers to sit on low stools or planks and still be in compliance with the new regulation?
meta_description: As the primary objective is to reduce the risk of workers falling off the lorry, the stools or planks that are provided... read more answers
content_answer: As the primary objective is to reduce the risk of workers falling off the lorry, the stools or planks that are provided for use by the workers so transported must be relatively low. For example, workers are unlikely to exceed 1.1 metres if they sit on low stools or planks that are no more than 20 centimetres in height from the surface of the carriage deck.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I carry workers on my lorry without displaying the Maximum Passenger Capacity (MPC) label?
meta_description: Lorry owners who wish to use their lorries to carry their workers must display a Maximum Passenger Capacity (MPC) label... read more answers
content_answer: Lorry owners who wish to use their lorries to carry their workers must display a Maximum Passenger Capacity (MPC) label on the right side of lorry's rear tailboard indicating the maximum number of workers that can be transported when the carriage deck is empty. Please click here to find out more information on safety regulations for lorries carrying workers.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I install canopies that do not cover the entire carriage deck of the lorry?
meta_description: Canopies installed on the lorry need not necessarily cover the entire carriage deck. However, if you wish to use your l... read more answers
content_answer: Canopies installed on the lorry need not necessarily cover the entire carriage deck. However, if you wish to use your lorry to carry workers on the carriage deck, please ensure that all the workers so carried are safely seated under the canopy.  Come 1 August 2011, which MPC label should be affixed on the lorries? The one with the yellow background or the one with the black background? Lorries registered before 1 January 2010 and used to transport workers will continue to display MPC label with white characters on black background.  Lorries registered on or after 1 January 2010 and used to transport workers will display MPC label with black characters on yellow background.  Source: LTA

content_question: Do companies/lorry owners need to have their vehicles inspected after fitting higher side railings on their lorries?
meta_description: Lorry owners who use their vehicles to transport workers have to ensure that the side railings fitted on the lorry is o... read more answers
content_answer: Lorry owners who use their vehicles to transport workers have to ensure that the side railings fitted on the lorry is of a design and construction approved by LTA and they are securely and rigidly attached to the lorry\xe2\x80\x99s sideboards when in use.  Source: LTA

content_question: Do I need to get my lorry inspected after installing canopies?
meta_description: After installing the canopy, vehicle owners are required to produce their vehicles for a \xe2\x80\x9cchange-of-vehicle-particulars... read more answers
content_answer: After installing the canopy, vehicle owners are required to produce their vehicles for a \xe2\x80\x9cchange-of-vehicle-particulars (CVP)\xe2\x80\x9d inspection at LTA\xe2\x80\x99s authorised vehicle inspection centres.  Inspectors at the inspection centres will inspect the canopy structure and re-weigh the vehicle.  The inspection centre will also update LTA on the lorry\xe2\x80\x99s unladen weight and particulars.  A fee of $73 (excluding GST) is payable to the inspection centre for CVP inspection and weighing. The LTA-authorised vehicle inspection centres that provide both CVP inspection and weighing services are VICOM Inspection Centre Pte Ltd at 385 Sin Ming Drive, STA Inspection Pte Ltd at 302 Sin Ming Road and 249 Jalan Boon Lay, and JIC Inspection Services Pte Ltd at 53 Pioneer Road. Enforcement officers are not everywhere at all times. Hence, there would still be owners and drivers of lorries that will flout safety regulations when carrying workers. How is LTA going to address this? Everyone has a shared responsibility to make journeys safer for workers. Government\xe2\x80\x99s commitment is through implementing and enforcing the set of stringent measures as well as to continue to look into ways to improve safe driving practices. Employers have the legal and moral responsibilities to ensure the welfare and safety of their workers. Similarly, lorry drivers need to exercise care for their passengers and observe safe driving habits. The public can also help by calling LTA\xe2\x80\x99s Hotline to report any instances of non-compliance spotted on the roads.  Source: LTA

content_question: For lorries carrying workers, are canvas-type canopies allowed?
meta_description: The LTA has, in principle, no objection to the installation of canvas-type canopies so long as the canvas canopy and it... read more answers
content_answer: The LTA has, in principle, no objection to the installation of canvas-type canopies so long as the canvas canopy and its structure are securely mounted to the vehicle. The canopy must be able to provide adequate shelter for the workers transported.  Source: LTA

content_question: Higher side railings may cause obstruction when loading and unloading goods on the lorry. Can I install removable side railings on my lorry?
meta_description: You need to ensure that the removable side railings are of a design and construction approved by LTA and removable side... read more answers
content_answer: You need to ensure that the removable side railings are of a design and construction approved by LTA and removable side railings are securely and rigidly attached to the sideboard when in use. If you are unsure whether the removable side railing is of a design and construction approved by the LTA, you may contact LTA\xe2\x80\x99s Vehicle Engineering Division for verification. Please provide technical specifications of the removable side railings.  Source: LTA

content_question: How long would the installation of canopies and side railings on a lorry take?
meta_description: Installation will take about 2 to 5 days, depending on the size of the lorry.  Source: LTA
content_answer: Installation will take about 2 to 5 days, depending on the size of the lorry.  Source: LTA

content_question: How much does an MPC label cost?
meta_description: MPC labels should not cost more than $3 per piece.  Source: LTA
content_answer: MPC labels should not cost more than $3 per piece.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where can I purchase an MPC label?
meta_description: Such labels can be purchased from vehicle accessories shops and sign-craft shops.  Source: LTA
content_answer: Such labels can be purchased from vehicle accessories shops and sign-craft shops.  Source: LTA

content_question: How will higher side railings help improve the safety of workers transported on lorries?
meta_description: Higher side railings better shield and protect workers from being thrown out of the lorry in the event of an accident. ... read more answers
content_answer: Higher side railings better shield and protect workers from being thrown out of the lorry in the event of an accident. It also serves as a hand-hold for workers seated next to the sideboards.  Source: LTA

content_question: How can I report a lorry carrying excess workers?
meta_description: If you wish to report any instances of non-compliance spotted on the road (such as lorries carrying excess workers or i... read more answers
content_answer: If you wish to report any instances of non-compliance spotted on the road (such as lorries carrying excess workers or in a dangerous/precarious manner), please contact LTA at 1800-CALL LTA (1800-2255 582).  Source: LTA

content_question: Is there a height limit for canopies retrofitted on lorries?
meta_description: As a general guide, for light lorries, the height of the canopy structure must not exceed 1.35 times the height of the ... read more answers
content_answer: As a general guide, for light lorries, the height of the canopy structure must not exceed 1.35 times the height of the lorry's cabin when measured from the road surface. This is to ensure that the stability of the vehicle is not compromised. Should the height of the canopy structure exceed the guidelines, a Professional Engineer\xe2\x80\x99s (PE) certification will be required.  As for heavy lorries, the height of the canopy structure must not exceed 3.2 metres when measured from the road surface (regardless of the height of the lorry's cabin).  Similarly, a PE certification would be required if the height of the canopy structure exceeds the guidelines.  Lorry owners who wish to install customised canopy designs may liaise with their workshops and send the proposed design of the canopy structure/design and installation details to the Vehicle Engineering Division of the LTA for specific advice.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the documents that I need to bring along for the inspection of my lorry after installing canopy?
meta_description: Please bring along the following documents when making the application:   1.\tA complete Change of Vehicle Particular ... read more answers
content_answer: Please bring along the following documents when making the application:   1.\tA complete Change of Vehicle Particular (CVP) application form by the vehicle registered owner to install hood or canopy. The form can be downloaded from our OneMotoring website at https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/en/lta_information_guidelines/forms_download0.html=> Downloads => Change of Vehicle Particulars (CVP) Application Form or as attached (with your vehicle registration number); 2.\tVehicle registration document (Please login to e-Services@ONE.MOTORING to print out your vehicle registration details); 3.\tInvoice from the installer or workshop for the attachment of the hood/canopy; 4.\tSketch (with dimensions) showing the installed features (Sample Drawing of a Full Length Canopy or a Half Length Canopy); and 5.\tInstallation Details, if any.  Source: LTA

content_question: What should I do if I cannot meet the deadline to retrofit the higher side railings and canopies?
meta_description: You can still continue to use your  lorry to ferry goods and/or equipment.  However, your lorry cannot be used to carry... read more answers
content_answer: You can still continue to use your  lorry to ferry goods and/or equipment.  However, your lorry cannot be used to carry workers on the carriage deck if it is not retrofitted with a canopy and higher side railings by the stipulated deadlines.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are light lorries required to be retrofitted with canopies and higher side railings first?
meta_description: Given the mass advantage in collisions for heavy lorries, the priority for canopies and higher side railings is higher ... read more answers
content_answer: Given the mass advantage in collisions for heavy lorries, the priority for canopies and higher side railings is higher for a light lorry than a heavy one. LTA also took in feedback from the industry stakeholders that if the deadline for retrofitting of canopies and higher side railings were to be brought forward, implementation for light and heavy vehicles should be phased so as not to strain the capacity of workshops.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are workers more vulnerable when carried in light lorries?
meta_description: In a collision, a heavy vehicle, by virtue of its mass, will generally sustain a lower change in velocity when compared... read more answers
