content_answer: In a collision, a heavy vehicle, by virtue of its mass, will generally sustain a lower change in velocity when compared with a smaller/lighter vehicle. This means the forces of a collision experienced by passengers in heavier vehicles are likely to be lower than the forces experienced in lighter vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will I be penalised if I do not display the MPC label with the correct colour scheme?
meta_description: It is an offence to display the MPC label of incorrect colour scheme.  Source: LTA
content_answer: It is an offence to display the MPC label of incorrect colour scheme.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will the new measures apply to goods vans? Why?
meta_description: Goods vans are relatively safer than lorries as they are able to contain the passengers and prevent occupants from bein... read more answers
content_answer: Goods vans are relatively safer than lorries as they are able to contain the passengers and prevent occupants from being ejected from the vehicle in the event of a collision.  Goods vans are also generally not used for the mass transport of workers for commute trips but are used more for the transportation of goods or equipment as well as some attendants.   Source: LTA

content_question: Is there a deadline to change the speed limit label? What happens if the speed limit label is not changed in time?
meta_description: There is no time frame imposed for owners of light commercial vehicles to replace the existing speed limit discs.  We ... read more answers
content_answer: There is no time frame imposed for owners of light commercial vehicles to replace the existing speed limit discs.  We will leave it to the vehicle owners to make their own arrangements to change the speed limit label after the revised speed limit has come into effect.   Source: LTA

content_question: Can the light commercial vehicle still travel at 70km/h if it is not carrying workers?
meta_description: A light goods vehicle that is not carrying workers can travel at 70km/h only if the new speed limit label showing 70km/... read more answers
content_answer: A light goods vehicle that is not carrying workers can travel at 70km/h only if the new speed limit label showing 70km/h is displayed. Similarly, a small bus with seat belts for passengers can travel at 70km/h only if the 70km/h speed limit label is displayed. Hence, it is in the owners' interest to replace the speed limit label early.  Source: LTA

content_question: Is there any change to the speed limits for heavy commercial vehicles? What is the speed limit for such vehicles?
meta_description: The revised speed limit does not apply to heavy commercial vehicles. Such vehicles must not exceed the posted road spee... read more answers
content_answer: The revised speed limit does not apply to heavy commercial vehicles. Such vehicles must not exceed the posted road speed limits, or vehicle speed limits which are currently set at 40km/h to 60km/h, depending on the class of vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: Must I obtain LTA's approval for installing passenger seat belts in my bus?
meta_description: Buses to be fitted with seat belts would be subjected to LTA's approval. Prior to granting approval, the LTA would chec... read more answers
content_answer: Buses to be fitted with seat belts would be subjected to LTA's approval. Prior to granting approval, the LTA would check to ensure that all seat belts and seat belt anchorage points fitted in the bus comply with internationally recognised standards (e.g. ECE standard, British standard, etc.).   Source: LTA

content_question: What are the documents that must be submitted to install passenger seat belts in my bus?
meta_description: \xe2\x80\xa2\tCalculations endorsed by Professional Engineer (Mechanical) on the seat belt anchorage points, seat mounting and inst... read more answers
content_answer: \xe2\x80\xa2\tCalculations endorsed by Professional Engineer (Mechanical) on the seat belt anchorage points, seat mounting and installation details; and \xe2\x80\xa2\tCertification from Professional Engineer (Mechanical) to certify that the seat belt assembly together with seat complied with internationally recognised standard.  The bus would also be inspected to ensure proper installation and functioning of the seat belts.  Source: LTA

content_question: Must I reset the speed setting for the speed warning device (SWD) in my light goods vehicle to enjoy the higher vehicle speed limit?
meta_description: As light goods vehicles will continue to be subjected to the speed limit of 60km/h when they are carrying workers on th... read more answers
content_answer: As light goods vehicles will continue to be subjected to the speed limit of 60km/h when they are carrying workers on the vehicles' cargo decks/ compartments, it will be left to the owners of LGVs to decide whether to reset the speed warning buzzer from 60km/h to 70 km/h. There is no time frame imposed for owners who wish to reset or replace their SWD to comply with the new requirement. Should vehicle owners decide to change the speed setting, they can approach the relevant SWD agents for assistance.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the changes to vehicle speed limits?
meta_description: The speed limit for light commercial vehicles (i.e. light goods vehicle (LGVs), and small buses with maximum laden weig... read more answers
content_answer: The speed limit for light commercial vehicles (i.e. light goods vehicle (LGVs), and small buses with maximum laden weight not exceeding 3.5 tonnes and with seating capacity of up to 15 passengers) has been raised from 60km/h to 70km/h with effect from 7 March 2005. However, the following conditions will apply:  \xe2\x80\xa2\tLGVs will still be subject to the speed limit of 60km/h when carrying workers \xe2\x80\xa2\tOnly small buses fitted with seat belts would be permitted to travel up to 70km/h  Source: LTA

content_question: Where can I install seat belts for my buses and how much will it cost?
meta_description: Owners who wish to install passenger seat belts in their buses should contact their local motor dealers for assistance.... read more answers
content_answer: Owners who wish to install passenger seat belts in their buses should contact their local motor dealers for assistance. The cost of installing passenger seat belts varies between different makes and models of buses. Hence, interested owners should check with their local dealers on the cost of installing passenger seat belts in their buses.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where can owners change the speed limit label for their light commercial vehicles?
meta_description: Vehicle owners can purchase the revised speed limit labels at sign-craft shops, vehicle accessories shops or at any of ... read more answers
content_answer: Vehicle owners can purchase the revised speed limit labels at sign-craft shops, vehicle accessories shops or at any of the LTA-authorised vehicle inspection centres.  Source: LTA

content_question: Where should I display the speed limit label for light commercial vehicles & small buses?
meta_description: Speed limit labels with white characters on a black background must be prominently and indelibly affixed to the rear le... read more answers
content_answer: Speed limit labels with white characters on a black background must be prominently and indelibly affixed to the rear left-side or right-side of the vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are the speed limits for light commercial vehicles raised?
meta_description: The higher speed limit would allow light commercial vehicles to travel at higher speeds and narrow their speed differen... read more answers
content_answer: The higher speed limit would allow light commercial vehicles to travel at higher speeds and narrow their speed differential with other vehicles that have higher speed limits. This would improve the traffic flow on expressways without compromising road safety. However, these vehicles, as with other vehicles, would still be subjected to the posted speed limits on the roads.  For safety reasons, light goods vehicles carrying workers on the vehicles' cargo decks/compartments and small buses without seat belts for passengers will continue to be subjected to the speed limit of 60km/h.  Source: LTA

content_question: What is the speed limit label that should be affixed to a light commercial vehicle?
meta_description: Light goods vehicles shall be affixed with a speed limit label displaying 70km/h. However, such vehicles will still be ... read more answers
content_answer: Light goods vehicles shall be affixed with a speed limit label displaying 70km/h. However, such vehicles will still be subject to a maximum vehicle speed of 60km/h when carrying workers on the vehicles' cargo decks/compartments.  Only small buses with seat belts inspected and approved by LTA can affix a speed limit label of 70 km/h. Small buses without seat belts will still be affixed with a 60km/h speed limit label.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I go for my vehicle inspection without the inspection notice?
meta_description: If your vehicle is due for the periodic vehicle inspection, it is not necessary to bring along the notice of inspection... read more answers
content_answer: If your vehicle is due for the periodic vehicle inspection, it is not necessary to bring along the notice of inspection. The authorised vehicle inspection centres would have your vehicle details if it is due for the periodic vehicle inspection.  Source: LTA

content_question: Do I need an inspection letter to send my WEC/OPC for the yearly number plate inspection?
meta_description: All WECs/OPCs are required to undergo and pass an annual vehicle registration number plate seal inspection at any LTA-a... read more answers
content_answer: All WECs/OPCs are required to undergo and pass an annual vehicle registration number plate seal inspection at any LTA-authorised vehicle inspection centre prior to the renewal of road tax. Hence, there will not be any notice of inspection issued for the vehicle registration number plate seal inspection. The LTA-authorised vehicle inspection centres would have the vehicle details when you produce your car for the inspection.  Source: LTA

content_question: For the purpose of road tax renewal, what is the validity period of the inspection certificate?
meta_description: For the purpose of road tax renewal, the inspection certificate issued for the periodic inspection is valid for three m... read more answers
content_answer: For the purpose of road tax renewal, the inspection certificate issued for the periodic inspection is valid for three months from date of issue.  Source: LTA

content_question: How do I send my vehicle for inspection if my vehicle licence (road tax) has expired?
meta_description: As it is an offence for using an unlicensed vehicle, your vehicle must be towed to any authorised vehicle inspection ce... read more answers
content_answer: As it is an offence for using an unlicensed vehicle, your vehicle must be towed to any authorised vehicle inspection centre for inspection.  Source: LTA

content_question: How much does it cost to change vehicle license plate number?
meta_description: We do not issue vehicle licence plate. Cost of a pair of vehicle licence plate varies accordingly to the type, quality ... read more answers
content_answer: We do not issue vehicle licence plate. Cost of a pair of vehicle licence plate varies accordingly to the type, quality and whether it comes with a holder for the licence plate. You may wish to check with the licence plate maker or supplier.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the documents required for periodic vehicle inspection?
meta_description: A notice of inspection will be sent to you about 2 to 3 months before the vehicle's periodic vehicle inspection due dat... read more answers
content_answer: A notice of inspection will be sent to you about 2 to 3 months before the vehicle's periodic vehicle inspection due date, to inform you to produce your vehicle for the inspection at any inspection centre listed in the notice. You may wish to bring the notice with you.  Source: LTA

content_question: What is the cost of the number plate inspection for my Off-Peak Car (OPC) / Weekend Car (WEC)?
meta_description: The cost for annual OPC / WEC seal check is $10/- (excluding GST).  Source: LTA
content_answer: The cost for annual OPC / WEC seal check is $10/- (excluding GST).  Source: LTA

content_question: Am I eligible for the ETS if my existing vehicle is deregistered because (i) its COE has expired; or (ii) it has reached its 20-year lifespan?
meta_description: To be eligible for the scheme, the existing vehicle must have at least one day of COE life remaining or at least one da... read more answers
content_answer: To be eligible for the scheme, the existing vehicle must have at least one day of COE life remaining or at least one day of its statutory lifespan remaining at the point of deregistration. If your existing vehicle is deregistered due to the expiry of its COE, you will still be eligible for the scheme if the existing vehicle has at least one day of its statutory lifespan remaining at the point of deregistration. Similarly, if your existing vehicle is deregistered due to the expiry of its statutory lifespan, you will still be eligible for the scheme if the existing vehicle has at least one day of its COE life remaining at the point of deregistration.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I register a new vehicle under the ETS before I deregister my existing vehicle?
meta_description: No, the existing vehicle has to be deregistered and disposed of first. At the point when the replacement vehicle is reg... read more answers
content_answer: No, the existing vehicle has to be deregistered and disposed of first. At the point when the replacement vehicle is registered, the unused COE and/or a proportion of the remainder of the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s 20-year lifespan from the existing vehicle at deregistration can then be used to compute the discounted PQP payable for the replacement vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I retain the registration number of my existing vehicle if I plan to register my replacement vehicle under the ETS?
meta_description: Yes, you can retain the registration number of your existing vehicle before you deregister the vehicle or at the point ... read more answers
content_answer: Yes, you can retain the registration number of your existing vehicle before you deregister the vehicle or at the point of deregistering the vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I use other COE rebates of mine to offset the discounted PQP payable for my replacement vehicle?
meta_description: It can be used to offset the discounted PQP payable, including the minimum 10% payment.  Source: LTA
content_answer: It can be used to offset the discounted PQP payable, including the minimum 10% payment.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can the replacement vehicle be registered under a party other than the owner of the existing vehicle?
meta_description: No, both the existing vehicle to be deregistered and the replacement vehicle to be registered must be under the permane... read more answers
content_answer: No, both the existing vehicle to be deregistered and the replacement vehicle to be registered must be under the permanent ownership of the same registered owner. For vehicle owners who wish to transfer the replacement vehicle to another owner, they may apply for the transfer with LTA only after it is registered.  Source: LTA

content_question: How do I calculate the discounted Prevailing Quota Premium (PQP) that I have to pay under the ETS?
meta_description: The COE bonus for an owner of a Euro II/III Cat C diesel vehicle with maximum laden weight (MLW) of less than or equal ... read more answers
content_answer: The COE bonus for an owner of a Euro II/III Cat C diesel vehicle with maximum laden weight (MLW) of less than or equal to 3,500kg who replaces it with a Euro VI-compliant (or equivalent) vehicle is 35%. The COE bonus for an owner of a Euro II/III Cat C diesel vehicle with MLW more than 3,500kg who replaces it with a Euro VI-compliant (or equivalent) vehicle is 100%.  Source: LTA

content_question: ETS Scheme: How much time do I have to replace my existing vehicle after I have deregistered it and how long does the application of the replacement vehicle take?
meta_description: To be eligible for the scheme, the replacement vehicle must be registered within one monthfrom the date the existing ve... read more answers
content_answer: To be eligible for the scheme, the replacement vehicle must be registered within one monthfrom the date the existing vehicle is deregistered. For example, if the existing vehicle is deregistered on 31 Oct 2017, you would need to register the replacement vehicle by 30 Nov 2017. The deregistered vehicle must also be properly disposed of (i.e. scrapped or exported and COE rebate, if any, successfully granted) before the replacement vehicle can be registered.  Source: LTA

content_question: I have an eligible Euro II/III Category C diesel vehicle. Can I replace it with a vehicle that is of a different class or propellant type under ETS?
meta_description: Yes, as long as the replacement vehicle is a new Category C vehicle. It can be propelled by electricity/petrol/petrol-e... read more answers
content_answer: Yes, as long as the replacement vehicle is a new Category C vehicle. It can be propelled by electricity/petrol/petrol-electric/petrol-CNG/diesel/diesel-electric/diesel-CNG. The replacement vehicle also need not be of the same type as the existing vehicle (for example, an existing Light Goods Vehicle can be replaced with a Heavy Goods Vehicle). If the replacement vehicle is:  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0diesel-propelled (i.e. diesel/diesel-electric/diesel-CNG), it must be at least Euro VI-compliant. If the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s maximum laden weight (MLW) is less than or equal to 3,500kg, it can also be JPN2009 with Euro VI PN-compliant. If the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s MLW is more than 3,500kg, it can also be PPNLT with Euro VI PM-compliant;  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0non-diesel-propelled (i.e. CNG/petrol/petrol-CNG/petrol-electric), it must be at least Euro VI-compliant. If the vehicle is using Gasoline Direct Injection technology, it can also be JPN2009 with Euro VI PN-compliant. If the vehicle is using Port Fuel Injection technology, it can also be JPN2009-compliant. For vehicles tested to JPN2009 and using Gasoline Direct Injection engines not equipped with a NOx storage reduction catalyst, they are required to also comply with the JPN2009 PM limits or the Euro VI PM limits.  In addition, you must fulfill the registration conditions of the replacement vehicle, such as obtaining LTA\xe2\x80\x99s prior approval for registration of a private bus, private hire bus, etc.  Source: LTA

content_question: I have sold my eligible Category C diesel vehicle to a dealer for deregistration. Can I register a new vehicle under the ETS?
meta_description: No, both the existing vehicle to be deregistered and replacement vehicle that will be registered must be under the perm... read more answers
content_answer: No, both the existing vehicle to be deregistered and replacement vehicle that will be registered must be under the permanent ownership of the same registered owner.  Source: LTA

content_question: ETS Scheme: I have used, encashed or transferred the COE rebate from my deregistered vehicle. Am I still eligible to register a replacement vehicle under this scheme?
meta_description: You are eligible for the scheme if your existing vehicle and replacement vehicle meet all the ETS criteria. However, as... read more answers
content_answer: You are eligible for the scheme if your existing vehicle and replacement vehicle meet all the ETS criteria. However, as the COE rebate of your deregistered vehicle has been used, encashed or transferred, the rebate amount will be collected back at the point when the replacement vehicle is registered, and form part of the value of the new 10-year COE of the replacement vehicle. This value will be used to calculate the COE rebate which will be given upon the future deregistration of the replacement vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: I registered my Euro II diesel vehicle in October 2006 (after eligible registration cut off date of 30 Sep 2006). Am I still eligible for the scheme?
meta_description: If you are able to provide supporting documents certifying the emissions standards of the vehicle, we will assess the e... read more answers
content_answer: If you are able to provide supporting documents certifying the emissions standards of the vehicle, we will assess the eligibility of your vehicle for the scheme. Please submit your request and supporting documents at www.lta.gov.sg/feedback.  Source: LTA

content_question: My vehicle was laid up before it was deregistered. What will happen to the COE rebate from the non-user period?
meta_description: The unused COE during the non-user period will also be used to compute the discounted PQP payable for the replacement v... read more answers
content_answer: The unused COE during the non-user period will also be used to compute the discounted PQP payable for the replacement vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the key changes to the ETS compared to the previous scheme?
meta_description: The key changes are as follows:  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0COE bonus of 35%, up from 13%, for owners of Euro II/III Category C diesel Light G... read more answers
content_answer: The key changes are as follows:  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0COE bonus of 35%, up from 13%, for owners of Euro II/III Category C diesel Light Goods Vehicles[1](i.e. vehicles with Maximum Laden Weight (MLW) of less than or equal to 3,500kg) if they replace their vehicles with Euro VI-compliant (or its equivalent) vehicles. COE bonus for owners of Euro II/III Category C diesel vehicles with maximum laden weight (MLW) of more than 3,500kg replacing with Euro VI-compliant (or its equivalent) vehicles will remain at 100%;  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0ETS is no longer be applicable for owners of Pre-Euro/Euro I Category C diesel vehicles. As announced previously, ETS for Pre-Euro/Euro I has expired on 31 Jul 2017; and  \xe2\x80\xa2\xef\x82\xa0ETS will no longer be applicable for owners who turnover to Euro V-compliant (or equivalent) models; replacement vehicles have to meet or be better than Euro VI and equivalent standard.  Source: LTA

content_question: What conditions must the existing vehicle fulfil to be eligible for replacement under the ETS?
meta_description: Answer is attached.  Source: LTA
content_answer: Answer is attached.  Source: LTA

content_question: What conditions must the replacement vehicle fulfil to be eligible for the revised Early Turnover Scheme (ETS)?
meta_description: To be eligible for the revised Early Turnover Scheme (ETS), the replacement vehicle must be: \xe2\x80\xa2\tA Cat C vehicle and not... read more answers
content_answer: To be eligible for the revised Early Turnover Scheme (ETS), the replacement vehicle must be: \xe2\x80\xa2\tA Cat C vehicle and not COE-exempted. \xe2\x80\xa2\tAny vehicle type, e.g. an existing Light Goods Vehicle (LGV) can be replaced with a Heavy Goods Vehicle (HGV). However, the registered owner must fulfil the registration conditions of the replacement vehicle, such as obtaining LTA\xe2\x80\x99s prior approval for the registration of a private hire bus, etc; \xe2\x80\xa2\tElectric vehicle, or Euro VI-compliant if it is propelled by diesel, diesel-CNG, diesel-electric, CNG, petrol, petrol-CNG or petrol-electric; o\tDiesel, diesel-CNG or diesel-electric vehicles with maximum laden weight (MLW) of less than or equal to 3,500kg can also be JPN2009 with Euro VI Particle Number (PN)-compliant; o\tDiesel, diesel-CNG or diesel-electric vehicles with MLW of more than 3,500kg can also be PPNLT with Euro VI Particulate Matters (PM)-compliant; o\tPetrol, petrol-CNG, petrol-electric or CNG vehicles can also be JPN2009 with Euro VI Particle Number (PN)-compliant if using Gasoline Direct Injection technology, or JPN2009-compliant if using Port Fuel Injection technology. For vehicles tested to JPN2009 and using Gasoline Direct Injection engines not equipped with a NOx storage reduction catalyst, they are required to also comply with the JPN2009 PM limits or the Euro VI PM limits; \xe2\x80\xa2\tRegistered in the name of the last registered owner of the existing vehicle; and \xe2\x80\xa2\tRegistered within 1 month from the date of deregistration of the existing vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Who will benefit from the revised ETS?
meta_description: Owners of Euro II/III Category (Cat) C diesel vehicles (registered between 1 Jan 2001 and 30 Sep 2006) will benefit fro... read more answers
content_answer: Owners of Euro II/III Category (Cat) C diesel vehicles (registered between 1 Jan 2001 and 30 Sep 2006) will benefit from the enhanced scheme when they replace their vehicles with a Euro VI-compliant (or its equivalent) Cat C vehicle. The enhanced scheme runs from 1 Aug 2017 to 31 Jul 2019.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are COE-exempted vehicles not eligible for Early Turnover Scheme (ETS)?
meta_description: The Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) scheme is based on COE incentives, and is therefore not applicable for vehicles which a... read more answers
content_answer: The Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) scheme is based on COE incentives, and is therefore not applicable for vehicles which are already exempted from COE.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why are vehicles with maximum laden weight of more than 3,500kg (Heavy Goods Vehicles) given a higher bonus compared to vehicles with maximum laden weight of less than or equal to 3,500kg (Light Good Vehicles)?
meta_description: Heavy Goods Vehicles are more pollutive than Light Goods Vehicles on a per vehicle basis. Removing pollutive heavy vehi... read more answers
content_answer: Heavy Goods Vehicles are more pollutive than Light Goods Vehicles on a per vehicle basis. Removing pollutive heavy vehicles from the roads will result in commensurately higher health benefits. Hence, higher bonuses are given to incentivise owners of Euro II/III heavy vehicles to switch to cleaner alternatives.   Soure: LTA

content_question: Why did the Government increase the bonus given to vehicles with maximum laden weight of less than or equal to 3,500kg (Light Goods Vehicles)?
meta_description: Light goods vehicles are the most populous type of diesel commercial vehicle in Singapore and contribute significantly ... read more answers
content_answer: Light goods vehicles are the most populous type of diesel commercial vehicle in Singapore and contribute significantly to particulate matter, a pollutant for which we are lagging behind in our 2020 air quality targets. We need to encourage more of such eligible owners to turnover to newer and cleaner Euro VI or equivalent vehicles. We had also received feedback that the incentives provided for Light Goods Vehicles were too low compared to those for Heavy Goods Vehicles. The increased bonus is meant to incentivise higher turnover of Light Goods Vehicles, to achieve a greater improvement in air quality.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why is the ETS based on the deregistration date of the existing vehicle instead of the registration date of the replacement vehicle?
meta_description: This more accurately reflects the health benefits of turning over to a new vehicle, as the existing vehicle can continu... read more answers
content_answer: This more accurately reflects the health benefits of turning over to a new vehicle, as the existing vehicle can continue to be used until the deregistration date.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why is the Government no longer providing bonus for the turnover to Euro V or equivalent vehicles?
meta_description: Given that Euro VI emission standards for petrol and diesel vehicles will be mandated from 1 Sep 2017 and 1 Jan 2018 re... read more answers
content_answer: Given that Euro VI emission standards for petrol and diesel vehicles will be mandated from 1 Sep 2017 and 1 Jan 2018 respectively, any scheme to encourage turnover to Euro V or equivalent vehicles would be of low value.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why isn\xe2\x80\x99t the ETS for existing Pre-Euro/Euro I Category C diesel vehicles extended to 31 Jul 2019?
meta_description: As Category C vehicles have a 20-year statutory life, all Pre-Euro/Euro I Category C diesel vehicles will be phased out... read more answers
content_answer: As Category C vehicles have a 20-year statutory life, all Pre-Euro/Euro I Category C diesel vehicles will be phased out within the next four years due to the effect of statutory lifespans.  Source: LTA

content_question: Can I use, encash or sell the COE rebate from my existing vehicle after its deregistration?
meta_description: A COE rebate (where applicable) will be granted when your existing vehicle is deregistered and properly disposed of. As... read more answers
content_answer: A COE rebate (where applicable) will be granted when your existing vehicle is deregistered and properly disposed of. As per current procedure, you may use the COE rebate to offset the registration taxes of a new vehicle, or apply to LTA to refund the rebate amount to you in cash, or transfer it to another party. However, if you are taking part in the ETS, and if the COE rebate is used, encashed or transferred before your replacement vehicle is registered, the rebate amount will be collected back at the point when the replacement vehicle is registered, and form part of the value of the new 10-year COE of the replacement vehicle. This value will be used to calculate the COE rebate which will be given upon the future deregistration of the replacement vehicle.  Source: LTA

content_question: Will the Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) affect the COE quota and price?
meta_description: Vehicle owners who take up the Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) will not have to bid for a new COE. ETS replacements are ded... read more answers
content_answer: Vehicle owners who take up the Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) will not have to bid for a new COE. ETS replacements are deducted from the total number of deregistrations. While this leaves fewer Category C COEs available for bidding, demand for Category C COEs would also have decreased correspondingly by the number of replacement vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: How do I know whether the car I intend to purchase falls within the rebate or surcharge bands?
meta_description: You can look for the CEVS information at the bottom half of the FELS Label affixed on cars displayed for sale in the sh... read more answers
content_answer: You can look for the CEVS information at the bottom half of the FELS Label affixed on cars displayed for sale in the showrooms.    Source: LTA

content_question: Is there a minimum Additional Registration Fee (ARF) payable for cars under the CEVS?
meta_description: Cars are subject to a minimum Additional Registration Fee (ARF) payable of $5,000 under the CEVS.  This is because mode... read more answers
content_answer: Cars are subject to a minimum Additional Registration Fee (ARF) payable of $5,000 under the CEVS.  This is because models that have relatively low ARF payable and are already fuel-efficient do not need to be further incentivized.  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the rebate amounts for cars under the CEVS bandings?
meta_description: The CEVS banding and corresponding rebates for cars are as follows: CEVS BANDINGS FOR CARS Band\tCarbon emission\tREBAT... read more answers
content_answer: The CEVS banding and corresponding rebates for cars are as follows: CEVS BANDINGS FOR CARS Band\tCarbon emission\tREBATE \t \t  \t(CO2g/km)*\t(From 1 July 2015 to 31 December 2017), both dates inclusive A1\t0 to 95\t$30,000 A2\t96 to 105\t$15,000 A3\t106 to 120\t$10,000 A4\t121 to 135\t$5,000  * CO2/km bandings based on performance data from standardised test cycles  Source: LTA

content_question: What are the surcharge amounts for cars under the CEVS bandings?
meta_description: The CEVS bandings and corresponding registration surcharges for cars are as follows: CEVS BANDINGS FOR CARS Band\tCarb... read more answers
content_answer: The CEVS bandings and corresponding registration surcharges for cars are as follows: CEVS BANDINGS FOR CARS Band\tCarbon emission (CO2 g/km)*\tREGISTRATION SURCHARGE (From 1 July 2015 to 31 December 2017), both dates inclusive C1\t185 < CO2 < 200\t$5,000 C2\t200 < CO2 < 215\t$10,000 C3\t215 < CO2 < 230\t$15,000 C4\t230 < CO2\t$30,000 \t\t * CO2/km bandings based on performance data from standardised test cycles  Source: LTA

content_question: Are imported used cars which fall into the rebate/incentive bands under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) exempted from the $10,000 surcharge?
meta_description: No, a $10,000 surcharge is payable for all imported used cars regardless of whether the car falls into a rebate band or... read more answers
content_answer: No, a $10,000 surcharge is payable for all imported used cars regardless of whether the car falls into a rebate band or surcharge band.   Source: LTA

content_question: How was the subsidy (surcharge) quantum for each band under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) derived?
meta_description: The rebate/surcharge quanta are calibrated to be sufficiently salient to encourage vehicle owners to choose less pollut... read more answers
content_answer: The rebate/surcharge quanta are calibrated to be sufficiently salient to encourage vehicle owners to choose less pollutive vehicle models.  Source: LTA

content_question: How were the bands for Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) determined?
meta_description: Answer is attached.   Source: LTA
content_answer: Answer is attached.   Source: LTA

content_question: How were the bands for Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) determined?
meta_description: Answer is attached.   Source: LTA
content_answer: The VES bands were established based on the emission standards of the top new car registrations, consisting petrol, diesel and hybrid models. Currently the bands are set such that a good proportion of cars will qualify for rebates, while others will fall into the neutral band or be subjected to surcharges. The bands were calibrated to encourage car and taxi buyers to purchase overall less pollutive vehicles. The bands will be reviewed progressively to ensure they are relevant to technological improvements as well as with new models in the market.   Source: LTA

content_question: How will Preferential Additional Registration Fee (PARF) rebates be computed for cars under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES)? Will the VES surcharge be taken into consideration in the computation of PARF rebates?
meta_description: The PARF rebate is computed based on the actual ARF paid and the age of the car at deregistration. To be eligible for P... read more answers
content_answer: The PARF rebate is computed based on the actual ARF paid and the age of the car at deregistration. To be eligible for PARF benefits at the point of deregistration, the car must:         a. Not be more than 10 years old (from the original date of registration in the foreign country);       b. Have been licensed (i.e. have valid road tax) at all times in Singapore; and       c. Not be an imported used car registered before 1 September 2007. VES rebates granted are used to offset the ARF payable and would therefore affect the computation of the PARF rebates at the point of deregistration. Similar to the $10,000 surcharge imposed for imported used cars, VES surcharge would not be taken into consideration in the computation of PARF rebate since it is not part of the ARF paid.  Source: LTA

content_question: I have already entered into an agreement with a dealer to purchase a new car. How would I know if I will get to enjoy the rebate or be imposed with a surcharge under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES)? Will I get a refund if my car falls into the incentive band?
meta_description: The rebates and surcharges under the VES will take effect from 1 January 2018, to give consumers and the motor industry... read more answers
content_answer: The rebates and surcharges under the VES will take effect from 1 January 2018, to give consumers and the motor industry time to adjust to the new scheme. As the purchase agreement between car buyers and motor dealers are private agreements, car buyers are advised to approach their motor dealers directly to clarify the terms and conditions, including the refund policy, for their agreements.  Source LTA

content_question: I need a bigger car to ferry my large family; would I be penalised under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES)?
meta_description: The VES incentivises based on emission levels and not the size of the vehicle. Larger cars may fall into the neutral or... read more answers
content_answer: The VES incentivises based on emission levels and not the size of the vehicle. Larger cars may fall into the neutral or rebate bands if they have relatively cleaner emissions. For example, hybrid and electric models typically have cleaner emissions than petrol and diesel.   Source: LTA

content_question: If my vehicle does not have Particulate Matter (PM) emission information, which Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) band will I fall in?
meta_description: Cars and taxis that are registered from 1 January 2018 to 30 June 2018 (both dates inclusive) will be exempted from the... read more answers
content_answer: Cars and taxis that are registered from 1 January 2018 to 30 June 2018 (both dates inclusive) will be exempted from the PM criterion under the VES. Their VES band will be evaluated based on the worst performing emissions of four pollutants of hydrocarbons (HC), carbon oxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon dioxide (CO2) (i.e. PM emission is exempted during this interim period). Thereafter, cars and taxis that are registered from 1 July 2018 to 31 December 2019 (both dates inclusive) will have their VES band evaluated based on the worst performing emissions of five pollutants of HC, CO, NOx, PM and CO2. The PM emission of Port Fuel Injection (PFI) cars which have not been tested for their PM emission will be assumed to be the Euro 6 emission limits for PM under the VES, and will fall into the maximum VES surcharge band (i.e. $20,000 surcharge) regardless of the emissions of the remaining four pollutants of HC, CO, NOx and CO2.  Source: LTA

content_question: What is the Emission Factor for Electric Vehicles (EVs) and Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEVs) for the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES)?
meta_description: EVs and PHEVs consume electricity which produces carbon dioxide (CO2) emission at the point of power generation. An emi... read more answers
content_answer: EVs and PHEVs consume electricity which produces carbon dioxide (CO2) emission at the point of power generation. An emission factor of 0.4g CO2/Wh will be applied to the electricity energy consumption to compute the equivalent CO2 emission for EVs and PHEVs registered from 1 July 2017.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why does the Particulate Matter (PM) criterion under the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) only apply from 1 July 2018?
meta_description: This is to give the industry some time to prepare for the submission of PM results. Hence, the PM criterion for all veh... read more answers
content_answer: This is to give the industry some time to prepare for the submission of PM results. Hence, the PM criterion for all vehicles will only apply from 1 July 2018.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why does the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) have fewer bands than the Carbon Emission-Based Vehicle Scheme (CEVS), and why reduce the maximum rebate and surcharge amounts?
meta_description: The banding structure has been simplified and recalibrated with the introduction of four more pollutants to better enco... read more answers
content_answer: The banding structure has been simplified and recalibrated with the introduction of four more pollutants to better encourage car and taxi buyers to purchase overall less pollutive vehicles.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why does the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) not provide special incentives targeted at electric cars which have no tailpipe emissions?
meta_description: Although electric vehicles (EVs) do not have tailpipe emissions, they consume electricity which produces carbon dioxide... read more answers
content_answer: Although electric vehicles (EVs) do not have tailpipe emissions, they consume electricity which produces carbon dioxide (CO2) at the point of power generation. Electricity consumption is measured under the standardised test cycles. An emission factor is applied to the electricity consumption to compute the CO2 of the EV. As the electricity consumption of EVs accounts for negligible amounts of emissions of the four new pollutants at power generation, EVs are thus assumed to emit no hydrocarbons (HC), carbon oxide (CO), nitrogen oxides (NOx) or particular matter (PM). The emission factor applied is based on the Grid Emission Factor published by the Energy Market Authority (EMA), which is the amount of CO2 emissions produced for every unit of electricity generated from the burning of fossil fuels at the power stations in Singapore. The historical values of GEF can be found at .  Source: LTA

content_question: Why is the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) band based on the worst-performing pollutant, instead of a weighted average of the emission levels of all the pollutants?
meta_description: As different pollutants would result in different adverse health and environmental impact (e.g. emissions from diesel v... read more answers
content_answer: As different pollutants would result in different adverse health and environmental impact (e.g. emissions from diesel vehicles are carcinogenic, Particulate Matter (PM) pollutant is associated with decreased lung function, development of chronic bronchitis, stroke and premature death, Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) pollutant leads to the production of more ozone which inadvertently impair respiratory functions, etc.), it is not appropriate to trade off one pollutant for another through a weighted average system. Vehicles that contribute significantly to any one pollutant should not be incentivised under VES. By basing the rebate/surcharge on the worst-performing pollutant, only vehicles with low tailpipe emissions across all pollutants will be incentivised. This will better enable us to achieve our World Health Organisation (WHO) air quality and carbon dioxide (CO2) targets for 2020 and 2030.  Source: LTA

content_question: Why should pollutants other than carbon dioxide (CO2) be added to the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES)? Why are these other pollutants chosen?
meta_description: Based on empirical data and academic literature, vehicles of different technologies emit different amounts of pollutant... read more answers
content_answer: Based on empirical data and academic literature, vehicles of different technologies emit different amounts of pollutants. Petrol vehicles tend to produce more carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrocarbons (HC), whilst diesel vehicles are more carbon efficient, but produce more nitrogen oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (PM). The inclusion of various types of pollutants in the scheme allows for a more holistic evaluation of vehicle models and encourages the purchase of cleaner car and taxi models that not only emit lower levels of CO2, but also lower levels of other pollutants in order to further improve our ambient air quality.    The 5 pollutants were selected and based on our existing type approval emissions standards for new vehicles. Under the VES, the emission standards include pollutants such as HC, CO, NOx, PM and CO2.  The VES rebate or surcharge will be determined by the worst performing pollutant. The National Environment Agency (NEA) requires all new vehicles to be tested for their emissions. Only those that passed the emissions standards can be registered. These pollutants are also proven by scientific studies to have adverse impact to human health.  Source: LTA

content_question: How is the performance of Audi A3 1.0 TSFI Sedan?
meta_description: If you are talking about engine performance, the Audi A3 has an engine power of 116bhp.   Speed wise, the machine chu... read more answers
content_answer: If you are talking about engine performance, the Audi A3 has an engine power of 116bhp.   Speed wise, the machine churns out a respectable 200Nm of torque from 2000rpm - an impressive pace for an A3. Its\xe2\x80\x99 new stop-start function allows the engine to be cut off just before the car comes to a complete stop to save your precious drop of fuel.   The cons? Laggy re-ignition; this means slower take offs from the lights or junctions. Car is reviewed not as efficient as how Audi makes it out to be \xe2\x80\x93  test car averaged 12.5km per litre \xe2\x80\x93 far from its stated 21.3km per litre.  Overall, the Audi A3 is practical, comfortable and fuel efficient. Not too bad for a continental car.

content_answer: My condolences to you. You will need to need to apply for a Grant of Probate (if there is a Will) or Grant of Letters of Administration (in Intestacy) that will authorize you to deal with the deceased's assets. content_question: Is road hogging a traffic offence in Singapore?
meta_description: https://www.allsingaporestuff.com/article/lta-confirms-it-illegal-road-hog-singapore
content_answer: According to LTA, road hogging is an offence.   Vehicles with speed limit of < 60km/h failing to drive on the left-hand lane of expressway, and vehicles at slow speed failing to keep as close to the left-hand side of the road as possible will get a maximum of $1,000 and/or 3 months jail for first-time offenders.  Vehicles obstructing other vehicles moving at a faster speed will be fined a maximum of $1,000 and/or 3 months jail, with 4 demerit points for first-time offenders.  https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/en/on_the_roads/educational_materials/_jcr_content/main_par/tabctrl/tab-5/download_1073148309/file.res/NoRoadHogging_Brochure.pdf

content_question: I can't add my vehicle in the Motorist app. What's the issue?
meta_description: Hi Mel.. For my case.. My car currently is from Grabrental company.. No whom I suppose to get the 4 digit ID.. Pls Asst... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Alex, if you can\xe2\x80\x99t add your car onto the Motorist App, the first thing to check is, if there is a typo. Make sure you key in the last 4 characters of the owner\xe2\x80\x99s NRIC no. or company\xe2\x80\x99s ROC no. correctly. Take note that it is 3 numbers and 1 alphabet in this format (Eg. 123Z).   If you have verified that there is no typo, please double check that the owner of the car is correct. Sometimes, the vehicle may be owned by a company, or by the parents of the driver.   Take note that you will not be able to add your rental vehicle onto the Motorist App unless you have the owner\xe2\x80\x99s credentials.   In the rare case that after you tried all above and nothing works, just talk to Mel in the chat within the Motorist App and she will assist you directly.

content_question: Where are the traffic cameras in Singapore located?
meta_description: There are 5 types of traffic cameras, located all around Singapore.   There are 240 Red Light Cameras, typically loca... read more answers
content_answer: There are 5 types of traffic cameras, located all around Singapore.   There are 240 Red Light Cameras, typically located at traffic light junctions. There are 20 Fixed Speed Cameras, typically located at expressways or big roads. There are 5 Mobile Speed Cameras, typically located at under-developed areas with heavy vehicles. The Police Speed Laser Camera can be found in 53 locations, typically at speeding hotspots, accident-prone and high-risk areas such as overhead bridges, around corners and bends.  Check out this video to find out more on these cameras! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uD4F9obysO4  We have an article about it too! https://www.motorist.sg/article/127/5-types-of-traffic-cameras-in-singapore

content_question: What is omv and arf value? What does it mean if both of their values are the same? If i plan to buy a second hand car which is 8 or 9 years old, how do i calculate how much will i get after scraping at the end of 10 years?
meta_description: The listed OMV value is that of the first registration date of the vehicle. OMV stands for Open Market Value. OMV is as... read more answers
content_answer: The listed OMV value is that of the first registration date of the vehicle. OMV stands for Open Market Value. OMV is assessed by the Singapore Customs, based on the price actually paid or payable for the goods when sold for export to the country of importation.  The Additional Registration Fee (ARF) is a tax imposed upon registration of a vehicle. It is calculated based on a percentage of the Open Market Value (OMV) of the vehicle.  The ARF determines your PARF rebate which is a component of your de-registration value.  \xe2\x80\x94 At the end of 10 years you will get back the minimum PARF rebate, which is usually 50% of the ARF paid. The PARF rebate is computed based on the age of the car at de-registration. The age of the car is computed from the date of its registration in Singapore or its original registration in a foreign country, whichever is earlier.   You can also check the PARF amount here: 1. Go to https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/en.html  2. Click on Quick access > eServices & Info > COE/PARF > PARF/COE rebate on Deregistration.  3. Enter Carplate  4. Select ID type and Enter last 5 characters of Owner's ID (Eg 3288F)  5. Input Intended De-registration Date  4. Click on 'I Agree'

content_question: How do I sell my car through Motorist.my portal? What's the procedure like?
content_answer: 1. Submit your details online.  2. Once we have received your details, our Client Sales Executive (CSE) will submit your details for bidding (dealers will bid for the car). 3. Our CSE will contact you the next day to inform you of the highest quotation received for your vehicle. 4. If you accept the quotation, our CSE will arrange for the transaction of your car; which is hassle-free (you can choose your preferred location).  5. The full amount will be issued during the handover, and all paperwork will be handled for you.

content_question: What causes an engine to overheat?
content_answer: An overheated engine may be caused by these possible reasons:  - Leaking in coolant - Clogged cooling system - Radiator cap is weak  - Thermostat is stuck shut  - Electric cooling fan is not working  - Faulty fan clutch, slipping fan belt, or missing fan shroud  - Anti-freeze is too high or too low in concentration - Debris present in radiator or is collapsed  - Exhaust system is limited

content_question: What do I need to do before the transfer of ownership?
content_answer: You will be required to go through a vehicle inspection by Puspakom.   You are advised to book an appointment early with a Puspakom centre near you before sending your car for inspection, as some centres might be busy or overbooked. Take note of the reference number provided by the operator once you\xe2\x80\x99ve confirmed your preferred date and time.   On the actual day of inspection, please bring along your original VOC or Vehicle Registration card.  For original VOC, you are required to get a copy printed at JPJ. The owner of the vehicle must be present and there will be a fee charged for the reprinting.   You will also be asked by Puspakom if the buyer is paying in cash or taking a loan, therefore it is important for you to be aware of this prior to the inspection day.

content_question: How I can find a trustworthy mechanic?
content_answer: Here are some useful tips:  Word of mouth: Ask your family members and friends for recommendations. Find someone with the same car make and find out which workshop they use. Ask how their experience was like with the mechanic. Take a chance: Experience the mechanic first-hand by visiting his workshop for something minor such as an oil change. This allows you to see and experience their service before commiting to them. Start your search early: Don\xe2\x80\x99t wait until your car is in a bad shape before searching for a good and trustworthy mechanic. Speak to your dealers: Check their service department because, \xe2\x80\x9cNo one knows your car better than your dealer\xe2\x80\x9d.

content_question: What should I do if my have a vehicle breakdown in a tunnel?
meta_description: For vehicle breakdowns, follow these safety procedures: -\tStop your vehicle by the road shoulder if possible -\tSwitch... read more answers
content_answer: For vehicle breakdowns, follow these safety procedures: -\tStop your vehicle by the road shoulder if possible -\tSwitch on your hazard lights to warn other road users -\tUse the nearest emergency SOS phone to call LTA Operations Control Centre.  -\tLTA will send a vehicle recovery team to tow your vehicle to the nearest designated car park. -\tWhile waiting for your vehicle to be towed, you should find and stay on a raised platform on the road shoulder. You should also be waiting downstream of your vehicle -\tUnder no circumstances should you attempt to repair your vehicle in the tunnel -\tFor your own safety, you may be required to leave the tunnel via the nearest escape exit -\tIf you are unable to move your vehicle to the road shoulder, or if its unsafe to leave your car, stay in your vehicle and call for assistance For more information, head over to https://www.motorist.sg/article/171/everything-you-need-to-know-about-tunnel-safety-in-singapore.

content_question: What are the cons of driving with a low tank of fuel?
meta_description: Hi there! Driving with a low tank of fuel can cause harm to your car's fuel system because dirt and rust will accumulat... read more answers
content_answer: Hi there! Driving with a low tank of fuel can cause harm to your car's fuel system because dirt and rust will accumulate your gas tank. These sediments can enter your car's fuel system and clog its fuel filter if the petrol level in your car drops too low. Thus, to avoid going to a car workshop, it is best to drive around with at least half tank of gas.

content_question: Do hazard lights drain the car battery?
meta_description: Yes! Hazard lights can drain the battery of your car. Any electrical device in your vehicle can become a drain if its l... read more answers
content_answer: Yes! Hazard lights can drain the battery of your car. Any electrical device in your vehicle can become a drain if its left on such as headlights, radios, and even door pins. These things can be problematic if they are left operating when your vehicle's motor is off. Meanwhile when your car is running, the alternator powers the electronics. Also, the hazard lights are designed to use minimal power, to buffer the drain on your battery thus, eventually your hazard lights can and will drain your battery completely.

content_question: Is driving into JB with a low tank of fuel an offence?
meta_description: Hi there! Yes it is an offence. If you are caught with too little petrol, you will be told to drive back to Singapore t... read more answers
content_answer: Hi there! Yes it is an offence. If you are caught with too little petrol, you will be told to drive back to Singapore to top-up your petrol, and you can be fined up to $500 for ignoring this rule. The risk of leaving Singapore with low tank is that your car might run out of petrol and you might be stranded in the middle of a massive causeway jam. Nobody wants that right? Therefore, ensure that your tank is at least three-quarter full before heading to Johor.  For more tips on money-saving before planning your trip to Johor, you can read the full article here: https://bit.ly/2z9VYwC

content_question: What are the consequences of road rage?
meta_description: Road rage is a criminal offence in Singapore. For causing hurt, offenders can be jailed for up to two years and/or fine... read more answers
content_answer: Road rage is a criminal offence in Singapore. For causing hurt, offenders can be jailed for up to two years and/or fined up to S$5,000. If caught driving recklessly, offenders can be fined up to S$1,000 or face imprisonment for up to six months. Thus, you should avoid throwing your rage on the road. content_answer: Hi there! There are two kinds of emergency exit; Emergency Escape Staircase & Pedestrian Cross Passage Door   The Emergency Escape Staircase is located every 500 meters next to the extreme left lane, the exit leads to the street level. Pedestrian Cross Passage Door is located every 100 meters next to the extreme right lane, the exit leads to the opposite bound tunnel. content_question: How long will LTA take to inform me about my motoring-related transactions via mail/letter?
meta_description: From as early as June 2019, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will cease hardcopy letters for motoring-related transac... read more answers
content_answer: From as early as June 2019, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will cease hardcopy letters for motoring-related transactions. Instead of hardcopy letters, car owners will receive notifications and updates via SMS (short message service), or electronic letters through their One.Motoring account. According to LTA, this will apply to all transactions, except for summonses. For car owners who wish to continue receiving hardcopy letters, they will have to inform LTA by the end of May next year.  Or, you can just download our Motorist App! On your app, you can register your car into our system and we can help you manage LTA and vehicle matters, such as informing you if your car's road tax is up or when you get a summon (touch wood)!

content_answer: Hi there!  With effect from 1 October 2017, you must carry out all PHC/rental cars conversions online and pay S$100 administrative fee per conversion.  To convert your vehicle, login at www.onemotoring.com.sg > Digital Services > Convert Vehicle Type or Scheme (e.g. Normal Car to Private Hire Car or Revised Off-Peak Car, and Vice Versa) (Requires login). You will need: -   1. Vehicle registration number; and 2. S$100 payable by eNETS Debits/Credit Card.   Upon successful conversion, a receipt will be shown online. A letter will also be sent to your registered address.

content_answer: Hi there! Marked by a single yellow line is a normal bus lanes reserved solely for approved vehicles during peak hours with periods in between for normal motorists use. The operating hours will be from Monday to Friday at  7.30am - 9.30am & 5pm - 8pm.  Meanwhile, marked with yellow and red line are a full-day bus lane with the same purpose. However it operates throughout the morning peak hour to evening peak hour without the period in between: Monday to Saturday from 7.30am - 11pm. content_question: Under the LTA's Private Car Rental Scheme, are private car owners allowed to rent out their vehicles on weekends and public holidays?

content_answer: Hi there! Private car owners are allowed to rent out their vehicles on weekends and public holidays under the following terms and conditions:   - Vehicle must be registered under the name of a private individual.  (Company vehicles are not allowed under the scheme) - Vehicle is only allowed for private usage only  (No  chauffeur-driven plate/private hire rentals are allowed) - Car owner ensure insurance coverage for the period of rental (Hirer must meet the required age & driving experience  in the insurance policy) - Hirer must check that vehicle is adequately covered by insurance for period of rental  Do note that it's illegal to extend the rental period across weekdays. content_question: What are the measurements for our car licence plates?
meta_description: Hi there!  The characters must be 70mm, 50mm wide, and 10mm broad. The space between adjoining characters must be 10mm.... read more answers
content_answer: Hi there!  The characters must be 70mm, 50mm wide, and 10mm broad. The space between adjoining characters must be 10mm. Any space between letters and numbers must be 20mm. The margin between the nearest part of any character, and the top or bottom of the licence plate must be 10mm. The margin between the nearest part of any character, and the sides of the licence plate must be 20mm.  To get a better look at the measurements, you can refer to the image on this article: https://www.motorist.sg/article/203/5-fun-facts-about-your-car-licence-plate

content_question: How to apply for Malaysia VEP?
meta_description: Hey Sskhaw! Here's the Step by step guide on VEP Registration:  Step 1 Download the Touch and Go App and link it to ... read more answers
content_answer: Hey Sskhaw! Here's the Step by step guide on VEP Registration:  Step 1 Download the Touch and Go App and link it to your Touch and Go card.  Step 2 Visit https://vep.jpj.gov.my and register your vehicle using same email as your Touch and Go App.  Step 3 You will receive a Confirmation Email. Try to print all documents that they send via email - you will need to bring this with you.   Step 4  (2nd email) RFID Tag Collection Invitation email: this link does not work and you would need to log into the VEP website and select your collection date and venue.   Example:   Dear XXX,   Thank you for registering your Vehicle Entry Permit (VEP) online account. We would like you to present yourself at the VEP Tag Collection Centre in Malaysia to collect your VEP RFID Tag. You can collect your VEP RFID Tag at any of these four (4) VEP Tag Collection Centres:  1) Lima Kedai Toll Plaza 2) Pandan RnR 3) Gelang Patah Southbound RnR 4) Plaza Angsana Open Carpark C  Step 5 After selecting the time and venue, you will receive another email. Print that email and all documents attached to the email - you are required to bring this with you to the collection centre.   Take note :  Registration is RM10, we advise you to bring the exact amount.  Please also bring along the following documents:-  - Copy of your Passport - Insurance cover note - LTA Vehicle Log Print out from LTA website. - They will take all this docs.  As of now, there is only 1 lane for RFID clearance in JB Woodlands side. Tuas side is unclear.   If you frequently drive to JB, you may apply for this RFID so you need not worry on low Touch and Go card value. Simply top up using your debit/credit card into the app and they will deduct from there.  Hope this helps!  (Source: https://www.motorist.sg/article/444/how-to-apply-a-malaysia-vehicle-entry-permit-vep)

content_question: What I cannot change my Halogen Headlights to LED Headlights, cause it consumed more power n also it is dangerous, LED Headlights is much more safer n use less power
meta_description: Hi William, LTA does not allow for the installation of aftermarket head lights in Singapore. Vehicles should only be fi... read more answers
content_answer: Hi William, LTA does not allow for the installation of aftermarket head lights in Singapore. Vehicles should only be fitted with the default factory fitted head lamps as they meet international safety standards. Using aftermarket head lamps might be hazardous on the road as it might cause unwanted glare. Whatsmore, if the new headlights were not installed properly, there is a chance that it might not work properly, and driving at night without the vehicle's headlights on is an offence. Hope this helps William!

content_question: What is error code CM00031 on the LTA website? I received this when filing an appeal.
meta_description: Hi Jason, this error occurs when you copy your appeal from Microsoft Word and paste it on the LTA website.  Microsoft... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Jason, this error occurs when you copy your appeal from Microsoft Word and paste it on the LTA website.  Microsoft Word converts certain special characters and punctuations into unique (Unicode) characters that is not recognised by the LTA website. If you are drafting an appeal, I suggest you do so on the LTA website.  Alternatively, you may use this link (http://mzone.wire2air.com/mserver/vas/unicodedetect.aspx) to check for any invalid characters in your appeal.

content_question: What is the procedure to renew my coe for my motorcycle.
meta_description: In summary, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to pay the Prevailing Quota Premium (PQP) for your vehicle category to renew your COE. PQP is t... read more answers
content_answer: In summary, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to pay the Prevailing Quota Premium (PQP) for your vehicle category to renew your COE. PQP is the moving average of COE prices in the last 3 months. It varies monthly depending on the COE prices in the bidding exercises conducted in the last 3 months. You can renew your CEO for a period of 5 or 10 years. If you want to renew your vehicle for 5 years, you need to pay 50% of the PQP. However, vehicles under Categories A to D can only renew its COE for 5 years once and when the 5-year renewal period is over, it cannot be renewed and your vehicle would have to be deregistered. Motorcycles fall under Category D. If you\xe2\x80\x99re renewing for 10 years, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to pay the full price of PQP.   If you are looking to reloan your motorcycle COE, do head to this article for more information. https://www.motorist.sg/article/718/5-things-you-should-know-before-renewing-your-motorcycle-coe  There\xe2\x80\x99s no limit to how many times you can renew your COE in 10-year periods for vehicles with no statutory life spans (i.e Categories A, B, D). Vehicles that have reached the end of their statutory lifespan can no longer renew their COE.  There are 3 ways to renew your COE. 1.\tOnline  a.\tYou will need a sufficient amount in your bank account, and the payment limit for the amount you are paying. b.\tAn Internet Banking Account with Citibank, DBS, POSB, OCBC Plus!, Standard Chartered Bank or UOB (eNets Debit) -\tRenew your COE here: https://vrl.lta.gov.sg/lta/vrl/action/pubfunc?ID=RenewCOE 2.\tBy post.  a.\tComplete the application form and mail it with your PQP payment to the following address:  Land Transport Authority (LTA) Customer Service Centre 10 Sin Ming Drive Singapore 575701 Ensure that your form and payment reach LTA before your COE expires If you are paying by cheque, make the cheque payable to "LAND TRANSPORT AUTHORITY" and cross "A/C Payee Only". Please write your vehicle number(s) and contact number on the reverse side of your cheque. Post-dated cheques will not be accepted. If your COE has expired, LTA only accepts cashier\'s orders. Please do not send cash payment by post. The COE renewal application date is the date that LTA receives the application. The PQP rates you pay will be based on the application date or the COE expiry date, whichever is earlier. If LTA has not received the application, showing that you have mailed it out does not count as proof of the application.  3.\tAt LTA Customer Service Centre a.\tComplete the application form and submit it along with your PQP payment to the LTA Customer Service Centre at 10 Sin Ming Drive 575701 -\tIf your COE hasn\xe2\x80\x99t expired yet, you may pay by: o\tCash o\tCashier\xe2\x80\x99s order o\tNets or Diners Club card (If the payment does not exceed the daily transaction limit set by the bank) o\tCheque* -\tIf your COE has expired, you will be charged with a renewal fee in addition to your PQP. You may pay by: o\tCash o\tCashier\xe2\x80\x99s order o\tNets or Diners Club card (If the payment does not exceed the daily transaction limit set by the bank) Application form: https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/dam/onemotoring/Forms/Q02.pdf  Source: LTA

content_question: Do I need to inform JPJ if I changed my vehicle's colour?
content_answer: Yes. As required by section 12 (2) APJ 1987, the registered owner of a motor vehicle shall immediately inform the licensed registrar (JPJ) in writing of any circumstances or events that affect the resolution of any entry in the registered in respect of motor vehicles. However all changes has to be reported to the JPJ within 7 days.

content_question: Do I have to regularly bring my car for a vehicle inspection?
meta_description: In Singapore, vehicle owners are required to send their vehicles for regular vehicle inspections to ensure that they ma... read more answers
content_answer: In Singapore, vehicle owners are required to send their vehicles for regular vehicle inspections to ensure that they maintain their vehicles in roadworthy conditions to minimise potential hazards to all road users. The frequency of inspection increases as the vehicle becomes older. Cars aged 3 to 10 years old would have to go for inspection every 2 years or if it\xe2\x80\x99s aged more than 10 years, it has to be inspected annually.  Any vehicle that does not pass the inspection will not be able to renew its road tax and, hence, will not be allowed for use on the roads.

content_question: Do I need an autopass card to enter Singapore?
content_answer: All foreign-registered vehicles entering Singapore must possess a valid Autopass Card. As Autopass Card for one vehicle cannot be used for another vehicle. Each Autopass Card is linked to a vehicle and the vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s insurance expiry date.

content_question: What happens if I drive my OPC during restricted hours without an e-Day license?
meta_description: It is an offence to use a WEC/OPC/ROPC during restricted hours without and e-Day license. If you drove during restricte... read more answers
content_answer: It is an offence to use a WEC/OPC/ROPC during restricted hours without and e-Day license. If you drove during restricted hours without an e-Day license, you will have until 11:59PM the next day to buy an e-Day license. If you miss this deadline, you have 3 more days to declare to LTA and you have to pay a fee of $30.  IF you do not buy an e-Day license or declare usage of your during restricted hours within 5 days of usage, you may face a fine of up to $5,000 for the first offence, and a fine of up to $10,000 for subsequent offences.

content_question: Any ways we can enter Sentosa Island for free? The per entrance of 6 dollars per car quite heavy.
meta_description: Unfortunately, there isn't. The entrance fee to Sentosa Island ranges from $2 to $6 per entry, depending on the day and... read more answers
content_answer: Unfortunately, there isn't. The entrance fee to Sentosa Island ranges from $2 to $6 per entry, depending on the day and time. The cheapest time slot is during lunch (12nn to 2pm) and dinner (5pm to 7pm), when it's only $2 per entry. Otherwise, it's pricey at $6 per entry.  However, if you're a frequent visitor to Sentosa. I'd recommend getting the Sentosa Islander Membership which entitles you FREE entry into Sentosa via the Sentosa Boardwalk, Sentosa Express and Sentosa Gantry (drive-in). The annual pass costs $25 per year and assuming you drive there on the weekends when the entrance fee is $6, you only need to drive to Sentosa more than 4 times a year to make your money's worth. After your first year, renewal is only $20. The individual membership is non-transferrable though, and only entitles one car and one person to the entrance fee waivers.  If you\xe2\x80\x99re a dad or mum, get the family membership ($50) instead. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be the main cardholder and your children/relatives will be the supplementary members. (up to 4 pax, immediate family members only).

Your insurer will have the right to reject your claim or claim any sums they had paid towards the other driver\xe2\x80\x99s claim from you; \xe2\x80\xa2\tYou may lose your No Claim Discount when renewing your policy; or \xe2\x80\xa2\tYour insurer may decline to renew your policy altogether

content_question: Should I accept a private settlement after a car accident?

content_answer: Be on your guard if the other party refuses to notify the police. If he acknowledges that he is at fault and initiates a gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s agreement to compensate your loss in private, it is important to take into account the true cost of a private settlement. Most insurance policies contain a condition that specifies the driver must notify the insurer on any accident resulting in damage to person or vehicle. Failure to do so may be deemed as a policy violation and your entire insurance coverage may be voided as a result

content_question: Does paint protection actually work for cars?
content_answer: Paint protection can help keep your car looking shiny and even help improve resistance to scratches. It\xe2\x80\x99s worth having if it\xe2\x80\x99s being given away as part of the deal, but it needs to be applied correctly to work well. If this is done then it\xe2\x80\x99s a good option for keeping your car in good condition. However, there\xe2\x80\x99s still no guarantee your car will be scratch free with paint protection applied.

content_question: How do I rent and drive a car in Malaysia as a foreigner?
content_answer: You will require an international driving permit or a valid license issued by your government to drive in Malaysia. Car rental can be arranged through hotel or through various car rental companies which can be located through the Yellow Pages Directory. Major international car rental companies are also available in Malaysia.

content_question: Can I settle my traffic summonses online?
content_answer: Yes. Traffic summonses (JPJ and PDRM) can be done online through a third party website. You may log on to MyEG\'s website and complete your payment there. However, if there are summonses that have been issued with a "Warrant Date Expired", you need to proceed to the nearest Traffic Police counter to clear them.

content_question: Will I be entitled for PARF rebate if I renew my COE?
meta_description: A vehicle owner will be eligible for the PARF rebate if he renews the COE in advance, provided the following conditions... read more answers
content_answer: A vehicle owner will be eligible for the PARF rebate if he renews the COE in advance, provided the following conditions are fulfilled:  i. The car must be less than 10 years old (from the date of its registration in Singapore or the original date of its registration in the foreign country, whichever is earlier) at the time of deregistration;  ii. The car must have been licensed at all times (i.e. not laid up); and iii. Not be an imported used car registered before 1 September 2007.

content_question: Can I drive my vehicle to inspection centre for inspection during the lay up period?

content_answer: The vehicle must be towed or transported to any of the LTA's authorised inspection centres for an inspection. The vehicle cannot be driven on the road during the lay up period..

content_question: Can I transfer my vehicle if the COE renewal application is pending cheque clearance?
meta_description: You can transfer a vehicle with a pending COE renewal application if the current COE for the vehicle has not expired. ... read more answers
content_answer: You can transfer a vehicle with a pending COE renewal application if the current COE for the vehicle has not expired. However, if the current COE has already expired and the COE renewal application is still pending cheque clearance, you can only transfer the vehicle after the cheque payment for the Prevailing Quota Premium has been cleared, and the COE is renewed.

content_question: I have a car of my late father and its still not finish the loan. Can i sell the car and kindly let me know the procedure to proceed further.
content_answer: If NO LOAN  (1) Get the death certificate of the deceased and go to the Balai police and make a report statement.  (2) Get the report statement/letter and drive the car to JPJ for inspection. Check with JPJ system on how to transfer owndership to the respective person. The deceased's legal wife/children must be present to sign the documents.  (3) If the family has a lawyer, please ask advice from the lawyer to transfer the name to heir.    If GOT LOAN  (1) Get the death certificate of the deceased and go to the balai police and make a report statement/get a confirmation letter from the court (2) Get the report statement/letter to JPJ so that they can do the neccessary transfer to the heir (wife/kid) and continue with the father's loan. (3) Once ownership has been transferred, the  new owner of the car can decide to sell the car as usual .   OR   1) The family pays off the loan first and proceed with NO LOAN procedure above  Most importantly, you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to check with the JPJ system.

content_question: My car still left 6 year Coe, how much I can claim back if I scrap my car via LTA?
meta_description: The scrap value of your car depends on when do you intend to scrap/deregister your vehicle. If you intend to scrap your... read more answers
content_answer: The scrap value of your car depends on when do you intend to scrap/deregister your vehicle. If you intend to scrap your car before your COE expires, it is calculated based on the formula below:  Scrap Value = Total COE rebate + Total PARF rebate  Your COE rebate is pro-rated based on the remaining amount of your COE.  If you intend to drive your car till the very last day of your COE, here's the formula:  Scrap Value = Total PARF rebate  The easiest way to find out the current scrap value of your car, is to try out our complimentary scrap valuation service. On top of the COE rebate and Total PARF Rebate, you will also find out what is the current market value of your car body. You can go to http://motorist.sg/scrap-export-car to find out more.

content_question: Can I drive my vehicle straight to scrapyard to deregister my vehicle if my vehicle is still registered with valid road tax and insurance?
meta_description: \xc2\xb7       For PARF-eligible vehicles (eg. Cars less than 10 years old and taxis)  You may drive your vehicle to the scr... read more answers
content_answer: \xc2\xb7       For PARF-eligible vehicles (eg. Cars less than 10 years old and taxis)  You may drive your vehicle to the scrapyard/EPZ. After you arrive at the scrapyard/EPZ, you may then deregister your vehicle online by logging in to www.onemotoring.com.sg using your SingPass or CorpPass 2FA.  \xc2\xb7 For non-PARF eligible vehicles (eg. Motorcycle, commercial vehicles, etc.)  You may log in to www.onemotoring.com.sg using your SingPass or CorpPass 2FA to appoint yourself or authorise a 3rd party to deregister your vehicle at the scrapyard/EPZ. Thereafter, you may drive your vehicle to the scrapyard/EPZ within 5 calendar days.
