content_question: How do I check if a used car is accident free?
meta_description: Hi Krish, you can check the history your vehicle here https://www.mycarinfo.com.my/vehiclecheck.
content_answer: Hey Krish, here are 5 signs that a used car might not accident free. 1. Paint issue - Some may have patches, whether it's just a slightly different shade, a variance of the shine or completely mismatching colors between the various different body panels, it all points to a car that had its bodywork repaired. Still, do double check with the seller.  2. Replaced parts - Many drivers turn to a form of filler to fill in a dent or crack on a car. Whilst filler can help some dents vanish with barely a blemish left, the mixture can actually harm the body of the car if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t mixed properly. The filler mix can cause cracking around the dented area, discoloration and a weakened area that is vulnerable to general wear and tear in the long term.  3. Car doesn't drive straight - When a car couldn't drive straight it means the alignment is off. In the worst case scenario, it may even be a car that has a bent chassis that is impossible to be properly aligned. Never purchase such a vehicle without demanding for a realignment to be done, if possible, and ascertain that the issue has been rectified.  4. Visible creased panels - The malleable steel sheets, which make up most of a car, could crease upon the impact of a collision, and a proper repair job would see to it that the body of the car is straightened as much as possible. However, a shoddy repair job might leave concealed areas such as the boot floor or sections in the engine bay still visibly creased.  5. Unevenly worn tyres - Tyre treads that are worn on one side more than the other could be an indicator that the car has be in an accident. Check the framework surrounding the tyres, as well as the rims to see if they are scraped or dented. It could be a sign that the car has been involved in something serious.

content_question: If the previous owner of the second hand car I'm using is dead, and the car is still under his name, how should I renew my road tax?
content_answer: There are some documents which would be required to transfer a vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s ownership to a new owner as required by the Road Transport Department (JPJ).  7 documents are required for the transfer, however, one would depend on whether the individual passed away testate (with a will) or intestate (without a will).  Here are the 7 documents:  JPJ K3A form Death Certificate Identification Card (MyKad) or Passport of the successor or administrator Vehicle Ownership Grant or Vehicle Ownership Certificate (VOC) Grant of Probate OR Grant of Letter of Administration OR Form E or F or T from the Department of Director General of Lands and Mines (for those with a Small Estate Distribution Order) OR Amanah Raya Berhad Court Order (received with Grant Letter of Probate/ Administration) Puspakom B5 Transfer of Ownership Inspection report  Testate (with a will) When it comes to an individual who has passed away with a valid will, the succession (new owner) of the vehicle depends on whom the deceased has bequeathed the vehicle. The executor or executrix will need to apply to the court for a Grant of Probate, which is a court document that allows the transfer of vehicle ownership to the successor.  Intestate (without a will) Should an individual passed away without leaving a valid will, the order of succession usually falls in order of: the spouse, children, parents, sibling, or the closest next of kin, as per the Distribution Act 1958 (for Non-Muslims) and Syariah Distribution (for Muslims).  In such a situation, the administrator of the deceased assets must apply to the court for a Grant of Letter of Administration OR if the estate value is below RM2 million, a Small Estate Distribution Order according to the Small Estates (Distribution) Act 1955.

content_question: What documents I need to prepare if I want to sell my car? What are the procedures to sell my car using your service?
content_answer: Hi Peik Yein,  You can submit your car details at https://www.motorist.my/sell-car and get a free valuation. Once we get the necessary details, it will be placed on a bidding platform for used car dealers to bid.  We would provide you with the highest offer (T&C applies) and if you are satisfied, you can undergo an inspection by the dealer and the dealer would provide you with the agreed final offer.   After the prices are finalized and if there\xe2\x80\x99s an outstanding loan, it will be settled by the dealer before the car is transferred to the dealer. If loan is cleared and there\xe2\x80\x99s excess then the dealer will pay you the excess amount.  For company cars, the process flow follows the private seller\xe2\x80\x99s requirement. However, there are more documents required when it comes to selling a company car. The forms required consist of company registration forms 9 or 13, 24 and 49, copy of a director\xe2\x80\x99s identification card, an authorized letter by company for ownership transfer at JPJ, motor disposal resolution letter.

content_question: How to sell my car? Are there any T&C?
content_answer: Hi there, there are no hidden costs!   However, you, as the seller will have to send your car intended for sale to puspakom for inspection. The used car can only be sold with certified puspakom inspection forms. Normally you or an appointed agent would need to send the car to puspakom twice to get the required inspection papers, usually Form B5 and B7 (required by the bank)  for private cars. The inspectiion at puspakom incurs small fees, on top of agent\xe2\x80\x99s fee (if you choose to use one).

content_question: If I want to sell car do I need to go Puspakom to examine my car?
content_answer: Hi there, after you have finalised the price to sell at, the seller (yourself)/ an appointed agent would have to send the car you're selling to Puspakom for inspection as it can only be sold with certified puspakom inspection forms - usually Form B5 and B7 (required by banks) for private cars. This inspection incurs small fees, on top of agent's fee (should you choose to appoint one).

content_question: What is causing my steering wheel to shake while driving? It happens right after I start my car.
content_answer: The potential problems include improper wheel and tire balance, uneven tire wear, separated tire tread, out of round tires, damaged wheels and even loose lug nuts.  Many of these issues can be avoided by routine car inspections, such as a visual inspection of the wheels and tires, checking and adjusting tire pressure, and checking the tightness of lug nuts. Your regular maintenance schedule should include maintaining proper tire pressure, rotating the tires and balancing the wheels. Wheel alignment should also be performed at proper intervals.

content_question: Is it advisable to have an \xe2\x80\x9calways-on\xe2\x80\x9d camera in your car? Will it deplete the car battery faster?
meta_description: Hi Bert! It is always advisable to have your car camera to be set to "always-on" such there will be video evidence acce... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Bert! It is always advisable to have your car camera to be set to "always-on" such there will be video evidence accessible for your insurance claims.  https://www.motorist.sg/article/487/the-importance-of-owning-a-car-camera-in-singapore#  If your car camera is connected to your cigarette adapter on a car that shuts the power off to the cigarette port when the ignition is all the way off and the key is out then it will not drain the battery of your car.  However, if the cigarette adapter port has \xe2\x80\x9calways-on\xe2\x80\x9d power and does not lose power when your car is fully off, then the car camera will continue to be powered as it has a source of power and this may drain your car battery.  Source: https://dashcameras.net/

content_question: What if I beat the red light and am a p-plate driver?
meta_description: Hi Justin, there would be a $400 fine and 12 demerit points.   For a new motorist who is under one-year probation fro... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Justin, there would be a $400 fine and 12 demerit points.   For a new motorist who is under one-year probation from the date of grant of his driving licence, his new driving licence will be revoked and become invalid when he accumulates 13 or more demerit points during his probationary period. The licence holder will have to retake all the necessary driving tests (theory and practical) to obtain a licence to drive/ride again.

content_question: How long does the driving theory test last for?
meta_description: Hi Muthu,   The Basic Theory Test (BTT is for life), however the Final Theory Test (FTT) lasts for only 2 years from ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Muthu,   The Basic Theory Test (BTT is for life), however the Final Theory Test (FTT) lasts for only 2 years from when you passed the test.   If you have not completed your practical driving test within the 2 years of passing FTT, you would have to apply and take FTT again.   The passing mark for both BTT and FTT is 45/50 questions.   You can find out more here: https://www.motorist.sg/article/323/singapore-driving-licence-how-much-does-it-cost

content_question: How long do I need to wait if my driving license is evoked (when I'm still a p-plate driver)?
meta_description: Hi Dexter, if you accumulate more than 12 points, during your 1 year probation period, your license would be evoked.  ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Dexter, if you accumulate more than 12 points, during your 1 year probation period, your license would be evoked.   For new or probationary drivers, they can only amass 13 demerit points within 12 months. Not only will their licence be revoked, but they will not be able to retake the traffic police driving test for 12 months from the date that their licence was revoked.  For more, you can read here: https://www.motorist.sg/article/534/traffic-offences-in-singapore-demerit-points-composition-fines-2020-update

content_question: What can i do if a natural disaster happened that involved my car? (E.g flood, car fall, etc)
meta_description: Hi Pek Kong, you can check with your insurance agent to see if they cover for you.  A natural disaster is typically d... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Pek Kong,  If you do not have existing car insurance, fret not! Motorist offers comprehensive car insurance. Do submit an enquiry here: https://www.motorist.sg/car-loan-paperwork and our consultants would contact you soon.  If you have an existing insurance plan, you can check with your insurance agent to see if they cover for you.  A natural disaster is typically defined by travel insurance plans as \xe2\x80\x9ca flood, fire, hurricane, tornado, earthquake, volcanic eruption, blizzard, or avalanche that is due to natural causes.\xe2\x80\x9d But it is important to note that not all these disasters are included in every plan\xe2\x80\x99s description of coverage.  I would advise you to take all the necessary pictures and sending them to your insurance agent to see how much coverage they can offer you.

content_question: How to keep my number plate when I sell my car?
meta_description: Hi Spencer,   You can apply to retain the vehicle registration number (VRN) of your vehicle before it is transferred ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Spencer,   You can apply to retain the vehicle registration number (VRN) of your vehicle before it is transferred or deregistered, or after you have deregistered it. You can use the retained VRN on a new vehicle that you intend to register or an existing vehicle that you currently own.   However, there would be a fee, however, it would depend on whether you use it on a new or existing vehicle.  After you have retained your VRN, you have up to 12 months to use it.  You can pay a fee to further extend its validity.  For more info, you can visit: https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/home/selling-deregistering/retain-replace-vrn.html  Intending to sell your car? Sell your car and get a free valuation in 24 hours: https://www.motorist.sg/sell-car

content_answer: Hi Norman,   The penalty for forming up incorrectly when turning left or right is 4 demerit points and $130 fine. And if you obstructed the flow of traffic, it is another 4 demerit points and another $130 fine.

content_question: Recently no more voice alerts from co driver anymore after updates
meta_description: Hi Max,   Since the introduction of Android 5, several device manufacturers have added battery saving options that ca... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Max,   Since the introduction of Android 5, several device manufacturers have added battery saving options that can interfere with our Co-Driver feature and prevent it from monitoring your driving activity. If your Co-Driver stopped working some time after activating the feature, we advise checking for a battery saving mode on your device, then reactivate the feature.  Please scroll to your device manufacturer to see the specific steps: - Huawei - Samsung - Xiaomi - Oppo - Asus - Other  Huawei devices: If you are using Android 6 or above, please follow these steps to adjust battery saving settings on your device: - Go to Settings and in the search bar type "Ignore battery optimization". Tap Ignore battery optimization > Allowed and select All apps from the drop-down menu. - Search for Motorist and select Allow. - Next, you will need to configure the Phone Manager app. Open Phone Manager, go to Cleanup, and tap the Settings icon on the top right of the screen to disable automatic cleanup. - Next, you will need to configure the battery settings on your device (you can check the EMUI version on your device by going to Settings > About phone):  EMUI 8 - On your Huawei device, go to Settings > Battery and disable both Power saving mode and Ultra power saving mode. Tap Launch, then find and tap the Motorist app to disable the Manage automatically setting. Ensure Auto-launch, Secondary launch, and Run in background are all enabled and click OK.  EMUI 5 - On your Huawei device, go to Settings > Apps > Settings (small gear icon at the bottom of the screen) > Special Access > Ignore battery optimization. Change the view to show "All apps" and make sure to allow Motorist\'s setting. - Then go back to Settings > Apps > Settings (small gear icon at the bottom of the screen) > Special Access > Usage access > Motorist and set Allow usage access to ON. - Still in the Battery options, tap the Settings icon on the top right of the screen and ensure the Power-intensive prompt and Close excessively power-intensive apps settings are disabled.  EMUI 3 and 4 - On your Huawei device, go to Settings > All > Device > Power saving > Protected apps > Motorist and choose Power-intensive. Go to Settings > All > Device Manager > Startup Manager and add Motorist. Finally, go to Settings > Smart Assistance > Notification Panel and ensure the Notification settings option is disabled.  Other Huawei devices: - Open Settings > Device > Power saving > Protected apps > Motorist and turn it ON. - Open Settings > Device Manager > Startup Manager and add Motorist. - Disable Ultra Battery mode: Go to Settings > Smart assistance > Notification Panel and uncheck the Notification settings. - Block the Phone Manager app on the Family Portal, to prevent your child from forcing Motorist to close.  Note: depending on the device model these options may vary. You can find them using the search field at the top of the Settings screen.  Samsung devices: Samsung devices with Android 9 - Go to Settings > Apps, tap the menu icon (three vertical dots) and go to Special Access > Optimize Battery Usage. Change the view to show All apps and make sure to switch off Motorist\'s setting - Next, go to Settings > Device Care > Battery > Power mode and select High Performance (or Optimized Performance).  Samsung devices with Android 8 - Go to Settings > Apps, tap the menu icon (three vertical dots) and go to Special Access > Optimize Battery Usage. Change the view to show All apps and make sure to switch off Motorist\'s setting. - Go back to Settings > Device Maintenance > Battery > App power saving (Detail) > Motorist and toggle this option off. Tap Unmonitored Apps > Add apps > Motorist and tap Done. - Next, still under Settings > Device Maintenance > Battery, tap the menu icon (three vertical dots) > Advanced settings > App power monitor and disable Put unused apps to sleep and set the App power monitor to OFF.  Samsung devices with other Android versions - Go to Settings > Battery > App power saving (Detail) > Motorist and toggle the option to OFF. Next, on the same screen, turn off the App power saving option. - Then go to Settings > Power saving > Power saving mode and disable both settings. Make sure Ultra power saving mode is also turned off.  Note: depending on the device model those options may vary. You can find them using the search field at the top of the Settings screen.  Xiaomi devices: If you are using Android 6 or above, please follow these steps to adjust battery saving settings on your device: - Go to Settings > Manage apps and look for Motorist. - There, make sure the Autostart option is ON. - Then, check both App Permissions and Other Permissions, making sure that all options are allowed. - Finally, in Battery Saver, select the No restrictions option.  Oppo devices: If you are using Android 6 or above, please follow these steps to adjust battery saving settings on your device: - Go to Settings > App Management > Motorist > Enable Allow Auto Startup. - Tap Power Saver and select Allow Background Running. - On Oppo devices that have a \'Security Center\', open the Security Center app and go to Privacy Permissions > Startup manager > Allow Motorist. - On some Oppo devices (eg. R9, R11, and A37f) you will need to go to Settings > Battery > Others > Motorist and uncheck all settings. - On some other devices, you will need to go to Settings > Battery and storage > Battery manager and turn off Smart power saving. Tap Power consumption details > Optimize for excessive power consumption and uncheck Motorist.  Asus devices: If you are using Android 6 or above, please follow these steps to adjust battery saving settings on your device: - Go to Settings and in the search bar type "Ignore battery optimization". Tap Ignore battery optimization > Motorist. - Open the Asus Start Up Manager app and set Motorist to autostart. After that, please block this app on the Family Portal.  Other devices: - We recommend that you check for a Battery Saving mode in your device Settings. - On some devices, you will need to grant Motorist special battery usage permission in Settings > Battery > Menu (the three vertical dots) > Battery Optimization > All apps > Motorist.

content_question: Hey Guys, my car is going to be scrap next year February 2021. What are the procedures? How should I scrap my car and get a used car?
meta_description: Hi Malek, you can visit this link for more information and fill in your contact details so that our consultant can cont... read more answers

content_question: Hey Guys, my car is going to be scrap next year February 2021. What are the procedures? How should I scrap my car and get a used car?
meta_description: Hi Malek, you can visit this link for more information and fill in your contact details so that our consultant can cont... read more answers
content_answer: Generally, if you're looking to scrap your car, you can start off by getting a quotation first. That will help you know how much you will be getting back from the existing ride so you can plan for your finances for your next ride. Once you have a budget on hand, you can look around to see if there are any cars that fit your budget on Motorist's used car listing, SGCarMart, or even Carousell. If you require a loan, Motorist is able to assist you with the application and facilitate the finance portion of your purchase. Once that is done, you can proceed to accept the scrap offer for your car as a trade-in and just do a one-to-one exchange on handover day.   It is easier to buy a car with cash and budget in mind. If you do not need a car replacement immediately, feel free to scrap it once due then look for a car after. Should you require further assistance, you can reach out to Motorist with your contact details and their car specialist will be able to help you see if they have anything that fits your requirement at enquiry@motorist.sg

content_question: What should I do if my cashcard has expired and there\xe2\x80\x99s value in it?
meta_description: Hi Bron,   You are entitled to a full refund of the remaining stored value in the CashCard within 2 years after the v... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Bron,   You are entitled to a full refund of the remaining stored value in the CashCard within 2 years after the validity period. If your CashCard has expired for more than 2 calendar years after the Validity Period, NETS shall be entitled to levy a service charge of S$1.00 per month or such other amount as NETS may determine from time to time, such levy to be deducted monthly from the Stored Value commencing the month after the end of the two years until the Stored Value is fully depleted, or until the 72nd calendar month (6 calendar years), whichever is the earlier

content_question: What should I do if my cashcard is expiring?

content_answer: If your CashCard is not expired/faulty, you may proceed to do an immediate refund at any POSB/DBS, OCBC and UOB ATM, or at the NETS Customer Service Centre. For expired CashCards, please apply for a refund at the NETS Customer Service Centre.

content_question: hi. I'm driving a 5yrs coe car, now going 2 yr. my loan is 4 yrs. how can i know when can i sell my car.
meta_description: Hi there, do submit your details here: https://www.motorist.sg/sell-car & our consultants would be able to assist you!
content_answer: You are able to sell your car anytime as long as you are able to pay the bank. To check the outstanding full settlement amount, you can call your bank and they will provide you with the exact figure you need to pay. Then proceed to get a quote from https://www.motorist.sg/sell-car and see if what you'll be getting is enough to pay off the loan or do you require top-up. If the numbers work for you, you can proceed to get Motorist to assist you with your car sale.

content_question: Car broke down
meta_description: Hi Juliet,  Slow down and go to the road shoulder if possible.  Switch on the hazard lights.  Open the trunk and hoo... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Juliet,  Slow down and go to the road shoulder if possible.  Switch on the hazard lights.  Open the trunk and hood to alert other drivers.  Stay at the downstream of the vehicle, and behind the vehicle impact guardrail (VIG) if possible.  Do not allow passengers to remain in or around the vehicle.  Call the Tow Truck to bring it to the nearest service center to fix your vehicle issue.  Do not attempt to repair your vehicle on the expressway.

content_question: I p plate driver beat red light recently what is the cosequences. Can I make an apeal. I really don't realise.
meta_description: Hi Nadiah! You may check if you have any outstanding fines here https://vrl.lta.gov.sg/lta/vrl/action/pubfunc?ID=Enqui... read more answers
content_answer: There's usually no chance given for red light camera offence. An appeal will be a waste of time in most cases. As a P Plate driver, you will have 13 points. With 12 points deducted you can still continue driving but having a second point more added to your record will result in suspension.

content_question: I'm unable to renew my road tax. LTA prompts me with the following: We are unable to process your request. [UL03077]. What does this mean?
meta_description: You can renew road tax for 6 or 12 months. Before you can renew your road tax, you must meet the renewal prerequisites.... read more answers
content_answer: You can renew road tax for 6 or 12 months. Before you can renew your road tax, you must meet the renewal prerequisites. Your vehicle must:  - Be insured for the period of road tax you are paying - Pass the required vehicle inspection, if it is due - Clear any outstanding fines  If an inspection is due, you will receive a notice. For Weekend Cars/Off-Peak Cars/Revised Off-Peak Cars and Heavy Vehicles, there may also be additional prerequisites to meet.

content_question: How long can I hold my COE once I am successful in my bid
meta_description: Hi Fedde! Upon successful bidding, COEs in Categories A, B and D are valid for 6 months and COEs in Categories C and E... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Fedde! Upon successful bidding, COEs in Categories A, B and D are valid for 6 months and COEs in Categories C and E are valid for 3 months (\xe2\x80\x9cTemporary COE\xe2\x80\x9d). If the Temporary COE (TCOE) is not used by its expiry date, it will lapse and the bid deposit will not be refunded.  Source: One Motoring https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/dam/onemotoring/Buying/PDF/COE/ocoe.pdf#:~:text=Upon%20successful%20bidding%2C%20COEs%20in,(%E2%80%9CTemporary%20COE%E2%80%9D).

content_question: Can I scrap my car by myself using other company instead of my former company. Do I need to take out the icu unit before scrap. Is there any other things that I can take before scrap.
meta_description: It is much easier and faster to scrap your car through Motorist. You will get money for your car body and paper on the ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Malek, you can choose to take out the IU or leave it in your car. But now there is an option to transfer your deregistered IU at an authorised IU service centre. The IU must be in good working condition, as deemed by the inspection centre, and must be transferred within six months from the registration date of the vehicle. It can only be transferred among vehicles in the same class. Transferring the IU costs about S$18.73 at VICOM, inclusive of GST.  https://www.vicom.com.sg/Our-Services/iuservice  It is much easier and faster to scrap your car through Motorist. You will get money for your car body and paper on the spot without having the need to send the car to a scrapyard and waiting 1-2 months for LTA to refund you the vehicle PARF. Selling it via Motorist will allow you to get cash on the spot with no work required on your part.  https://www.motorist.sg/scrap-export-car  For more info about scrapping your car: https://www.motorist.sg/article/1/scrap-car-singapore-6-things-to-note

content_question: Hi guys , i kena fined for failed to notify register\xe2\x80\x99s particulars in making modifcation. I changed my exhaust pipe few months ago , went and pass my inspection. Then suddenly this i kena this saman. Anyone can advise me whats this saman for before i contact LTA. Thanks in advance.
meta_description: Hi Edo,   Modifications to the exhaust system requires the LTA approval: The exhaust system, which consists of the e... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Edo,   Modifications to the exhaust system requires the LTA approval: The exhaust system, which consists of the exhaust manifold, catalytic converter and muffler, is used as part of a vehicle's exhaust-emission control system to ensure that the exhaust emission meets environmental standards. Before modifying the exhaust system, you need to get LTA\xe2\x80\x99s approval by submitting these for evaluation:   1. Certification from the product manufacturer stating that the proposed aftermarket exhaust system is suitable for the make and model of the vehicle 2. Test reports from LTA- or NEA-recognised test laboratories to show that the aftermarket exhaust system, when fitted to your vehicle, complies with noise and exhaust emission standards for your vehicle model 3. You are not allowed to remove catalytic converters and mufflers, as it will adversely affect the exhaust emission characteristics of the vehicle.  You can read up more here: https://www.onemotoring.com.sg/content/onemotoring/home/owning/modification.html#List_of_Modifications  Hope this helps!

content_question: Just got into an accident, opposing party wants to claim my insurance but I am not at fault with proof, what will happen?
meta_description: Hi!  Did you collect the following? 1. Other driver's name and address 2. Other driver's insurance company name and ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi!  Did you collect the following? 1. Other driver's name and address 2. Other driver's insurance company name and policy information 3. Statements and contact information from witnesses 4. Take pictures of the accident scene -- most smartphone cameras are suitable. If you can take pictures of the cars as they sit right after the accident it is best. If you had to move due to safety concerns, then take photos of the damage to each vehicle. 5. All of the evidence gathered at the scene to bolster your position on the cause of the accident. -- First, inform the other person's insurer that you have been involved in a crash with one of its policyholders. Relay only the facts of the accident, even if you believe the other driver to be at fault, it\xe2\x80\x99s not smart to just say that. Instead, give the insurer the facts to show their driver is at fault and liable for your damages. -- Although you may feel that you have not caused the accident, you might want to contact your insurance company anyway. This establishes your good-faith accident-reporting effort and can aid you if the other party's insurer denies responsibility for the accident or it turns out their insurance was not valid at the time of the incident and you need to make a collision claim.

content_question: In the four way junction, if I go straight with the green light, however my exit road not clear. Then I stuck in the yellow box in the junction when the traffic turns red. What should I do?
meta_description: Hi Lin!  Getting stuck in a yellow box is against traffic rules and could also be highly frustrating for other road us... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Lin!  Getting stuck in a yellow box is against traffic rules and could also be highly frustrating for other road users. You might find yourself blocking traffic from other directions, which might lead drivers to perform dangerous manoeuvres to avoid you. If you ever find yourself stuck in a yellow box, be aware of cars coming from different directions - so check all around before moving off. -  If caught, there are no demerit points but there would be a composition fine of $100 for light vehicles and $150 for heavy vehicles.

content_question: What do I have to do when I knock a pedestrian
meta_description: It is absolutely imperative that you do not flee the scene if you have struck a pedestrian with your vehicle. This coul... read more answers
content_answer: It is absolutely imperative that you do not flee the scene if you have struck a pedestrian with your vehicle. This could lead to a hit and run charge in addition to hitting a pedestrian. Immediately stop your vehicle in a safe area and call 911. Render any aid you are capable of, and ask any witnesses to remain on the scene. If the pedestrian is conscious and able, exchange relevant information such as names, phone numbers, and insurance providers. - Once the police arrive, give your statement, but do not admit or imply fault to anyone. This includes apologizing and stating that you did not see the pedestrian. If you are allowed to, take photos of any damages, as well as the surrounding area and any injuries. Speak to an attorney as soon as possible, as they will be able to further advise you. Finally, report the incident to your insurance provider. You will generally have thirty days to do so, and your attorney can guide you through this process. - Unless stated in a state\xe2\x80\x99s statutes, ordinances, or road signs, pedestrians may cross either directly or diagonally at any point in the road. If a pedestrian is found guilty of jaywalking, they could be found at least partially at fault for an accident involving a vehicle hitting them. Many laws have restricted pedestrian crossing to crosswalks, and only at right angles.  You may read more information about this at: https://www.legalmatch.com/law-library/article/what-happens-if-i-hit-a-pedestrian.html#:~:text=It%20is%20absolutely%20imperative%20that,safe%20area%20and%20call%20911.

content_question: My left side daytime LED light is not turning on. But LED light is on when I switched on the headlights. Is it fuse or need to change the whole headlight?
meta_description: Hi! Usually, the daytime running lamps cannot be manually turned on and off and are controlled automatically by the da... read more answers
content_answer: Hi! Usually, the daytime running lamps cannot be manually turned on and off and are controlled automatically by the daytime running lamp module. The daytime running lamp module is the computer that controls the daytime running lamps, and any issues with the module can cause the lamps to not function properly. Usually, a bad or failing daytime running lamp module will produce a few symptoms that can alert the driver of a potential problem that should be serviced. - Some symptoms include:  1. Daytime running lamps do not come on 2. Daytime running lamps stay on while the car is off 3. Burning smell - Do take note if any of the symptoms are showing. If they are, you should have the vehicle inspected by a professional technician, to determine if your car needs a daytime running lamp module replacement.  -  As they are a separate light from the actual headlights, there is a low chance that you might need to change the whole headlight.

content_question: I moved into the right turn waiting pocket on green light, after the opposite traffic is cleared, lights at all directions are red and there\xe2\x80\x99s no arrow light at that junction, now can I continue turning or should I wait until the light turns green?
meta_description: Hi Qing!  This is known as a 'Discretionary Right-Turn'.  Drivers are supposed to wait in the right-turning pocket at... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Qing!  This is known as a 'Discretionary Right-Turn'.  Drivers are supposed to wait in the right-turning pocket at junctions, and only execute the turn if traffic is clear. content_question: Hi can I know driving license point adding how many month after...?
meta_description: Hi Jamal!  For new or probationary drivers, they can only amass 13 demerit points within 12 months. Not only will thei... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Jamal!  For new or probationary drivers, they can only amass 13 demerit points within 12 months. Not only will their licence be revoked, but they will not be able to retake the traffic police driving test for 12 months from the date that their licence was revoked. After the first year, drivers can accumulate less than 24 demerit points within 24 months or he/she will be suspended from driving. You can read more here:https://www.motorist.sg/article/534/traffic-offences-in-singapore-demerit-points-composition-fines-2021-update - If you are looking to check your driving license points, you may do so here: https://eservices.police.gov.sg/content/policehubhome/homepage/enquiry/status-of-driver-improvement-points.html.

content_question: Change of IU
meta_description: Hi Razi! You have the option to transfer your deregistered IU at an authorised IU service centre. - The IU must be i... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Razi! You have the option to transfer your deregistered IU at an authorised IU service centre. - The IU must be in good working condition, as deemed by the inspection centre, and must be transferred within six months from the registration date of the vehicle. It can only be transferred among vehicles in the same class. Transferring the IU costs about S$18.73 at VICOM, inclusive of GST. - For more info about the IU units, you can read our article here https://www.motorist.sg/article/524/everything-you-need-to-know-about-your-in-vehicle-unit-iu

content_question: Hi, so i last minute saw the light turned amber and I emergency braked and I managed to stop ontop of the sensor, basically got 2 rectangular boxnI managed to stop ontop of the first box. Will I still get fined and points?
meta_description: Hi Sham! A flash is taken once your wheel crosses the line based on the sensors, but they will assess if at the point o... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Sham! A flash is taken once your wheel crosses the line based on the sensors, but they will assess if at the point of the first flash your car had already passed the so-called point of no return. To see where the sensors are on the roads and you will understand what I mean. They are not on the white line. Your wheels have front and back if your front already crossed the line and the back was still on the sensor when it became red, it will still flash. If your front wheels crossed but you stop in-between lines. It will also flash but you will not be fine because you did not cross during the second flash.  But it's still individually accessed, you might have to wait and see if you get a letter from TP.

content_question: Let say road tax of sg registered motorbike is expired it was parked in JB. Will there be any consequence if unable send for inspection and renew road tax in this period. What to do supposedly?
meta_description: Hi Colin! You may still renew your COE by bank transfer via OneMotoring. For those intending to renew your COE, you hav... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Colin! You may still renew your COE by bank transfer via OneMotoring. For those intending to renew your COE, you have one month to do so after your COE expires, but you will be subjected to late renewal fees from S$50 to $250. This is payable, regardless of the impact caused by the Circuit Breaker. - If you\xe2\x80\x99re unable to renew within one month after your COE expires, you may have to contact LTA and request for an extension. However, this is a case by case basis, and it will be highly unlikely that your request will be granted. Your vehicle will be automatically deregistered if an extension is not granted and you won't be able to renew its COE again.  You can read more here: https://www.motorist.sg/article/577/covid-19-circuit-breaker-new-measures-that-may-impact-you-as-a-vehicle-owner

content_question: Will red light camera capture by mistake? I was making a right turn on 2nd lane (go-straight/right-turn shared lane) at the T-junction of paya lebar rd x Ubi ave 3. The traffic light for going straight was red but right turn arrow was green flickering while I passed the stop line. However, I received notice of offence for beating red light. I wanted to appeal but TP website states only accepts medical reason. I did not realize for any abnormal event so did not download footage from in-car camera, and the video already washed away by new recordings while I received the letter. Attached picture is screenshot from google map, it is the view from 1st (right turn) lane, I was on the 2nd lane, right turn arrow was blinking. In such case, what should I do? Can I appeal?
meta_description: Hi Ya, red light cameras usually do not capture by mistake.  -  May I suggest that you contact LTA to notify them about your situation?
content_answer: Hi Ya, red light cameras usually do not capture by mistake.  -  May I suggest that you contact LTA to notify them about your situation?

content_question: Can the windows at the Left/Right sliding doors and rear windscreen of a commercial van be fully covered to ensure the security of the cargo?
meta_description: Hi Normanshah,   LTA has no objection to the display of sticker advertisements or decals on vehicles so long as the f... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Normanshah,   LTA has no objection to the display of sticker advertisements or decals on vehicles so long as the following requirements are complied with:  a) no part of the stickers shall obstruct the view of the driver or pose any danger to other road users;  b) the stickers do not cover or mask any lighting systems, number plates, windows, windscreens, and other pre-requisite markings/labels on the vehicle (e.g. speed limit, maximum passenger capacity, company information for goods vehicles etc);  c) graphics and/or words shall not appear in any way pornographic, obscene or vulgar. They must also not be seditious or affront any religious belief;  d) the basic colour of the vehicle must be maintained;  e) if the stickers are intended to be pasted across the windscreens and windows, they must not be more than 150mm (6 inches) measured from the top edge of the front windscreen and not more than 100mm (4 inches) measured from the top edge of the rear windscreen and side windows; and  f) the resultant light transmittance for remaining areas of the front windscreen and both front windows must be at least 70%; and the rear windscreen and rear passenger windows must be at least 25%.  Source:LTA

content_answer: Hi Anthony! It should be working in the day and at night and is triggered when someone beats the red light. content_answer: Hi Bing Xiang!   Effective from 16 February 2021, duties for premium petrol (98 Octane and above) will be raised by 15 cents per litre to 79 cents per litre, whereas intermediate petrol will see a rise of 10 cents per litre to 66 cents per litre. However, vehicles will also enjoy road tax rebates for a year, from 1 August 2021 till 31 July 2022. - https://www.motorist.sg/article/804/singapore-budget-petrol-duties-up-with-immediate-effect

content_question: When do I need go for my car inspection.
meta_description: Hi Joe! In Singapore, vehicle owners are required to send their vehicles for regular vehicle inspections to ensure that... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Joe! In Singapore, vehicle owners are required to send their vehicles for regular vehicle inspections to ensure that they maintain their vehicles in roadworthy conditions to minimise potential hazards to all road users. The frequency of inspection increases as the vehicle becomes older. Cars aged 3 to 10 years old would have to go for inspection every 2 years or if it\xe2\x80\x99s aged more than 10 years, it has to be inspected annually. Any vehicle that does not pass the inspection will not be able to renew its road tax and, hence, will not be allowed for use on the roads.

content_question: Hi...My demerit point deducted 14point on 2019 October... Will I get back all my point at 2020 October?
meta_description: 2 years without offense will "spent" your demerit points.
content_answer: 2 years without offense will "spent" your demerit points.

content_question: Hi...My demerit point deducted 14point on 2019 October... Will I get back all my point at 2020 October?
meta_description: 2 years without offense will "spent" your demerit points.
content_answer: Under the Driver Improvement Point System (DIPS), any demerit points will be erased if the driver remains free from traffic offences for the 12 months following his last offence. - Any suspensions would also be wiped off his/her driving record if he remains free from traffic offences for two years from the time his licence was suspended. However, if the period of driving suspension is one year or longer, he/she will have to earn it back later on by passing the theory and practical exams all over again. - The best incentive will be the Certificate of Merit, issued to every motorist who maintains a clean driving record consecutively for three years. This reward entitles him/her to a five percent discount on his/her motor insurance premium upon renewal, on top of any No-Claim Bonus, provided his/her insurer participates in the above-mentioned scheme and he/she did not file any policy claims in the last three years.

content_question: Speeding 21 to 30km..What is the fine
meta_description: Hi Jason! If your speed limit exceeded by 21 to 30 km/h, 6 demerit points will be awarded. You would receive a notifica... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Jason! If your speed limit exceeded by 21 to 30 km/h, 6 demerit points will be awarded. You would receive a notification letter informing you of your demerit point status.  - **Revocation/suspension of driving licence If you are a new or probationary driver, your driving licence will be revoked and become invalid should you accumulate 13 or more demerit points during your 1-year probation period.  You would have to re-attempt both the traffic police theory and practical tests to obtain a new driving licence.  For non-probationary drivers with no previous suspension records, your driving licence will become liable for suspension for up to 12 weeks if you accumulate 24 or more demerit points within 24 consecutive months.  For non-probationary drivers who have been previously suspended at least once, your driving licence will be liable for suspension for up to 36 months (depending on how many times you have previously been suspended) if you accumulate 12 or more demerit points within 12 consecutive months.  For more info: https://singaporelegaladvice.com/law-articles/caught-speeding-singapore/

content_answer: Hi Putraa! Yes, you can buy a car without a license. The driver of the vehicle will have to be named in the car insurance document which is known as the 'insured not driving policy'.  It is basically a declaration that you will not be driving the vehicle, and that you will contact the insurer if there are any changes in future.  You can find the document here: http://www.aig.com.sg/content/dam/aig/apac/singapore/documents/forms/non-driver-undertaking_letter.pdf

content_question: Is there a 0% down payment for new cars
meta_description: 0% downpayment is basically working around to the system for most people. This will typically mean marking up the value... read more answers
content_answer: 0% downpayment is basically working around to the system for most people. This will typically mean marking up the value of the car for the bank to see in order to secure a higher loan. The only time you can purchase a new car with 100% loan is for a commercial vehicle or private hire vehicle.   There are companies offering 100% loans in exchange for higher interest rates but it is highly not advisable to buy a car without having enough financing as you may find difficulty servicing your loan if you do need to sell your ride before fully paying for the car.

content_question: Can I remove the private hire car decal myself after I have converted the car from private hire car to passenger car?
meta_description: Yup you can!  - The tamper-evident decals (\xe2\x80\x9cdecals\xe2\x80\x9d) are required to be displayed at all times, regardless of usage o... read more answers
content_answer: Yup you can!  - The tamper-evident decals (\xe2\x80\x9cdecals\xe2\x80\x9d) are required to be displayed at all times, regardless of usage of vehicle. If the chauffeured Private Hire Cars (PHCs) are converted out of the class and body codes Z10/Z11/Z16/Z17, the vehicle owners must remove and dispose of the decals. They do not need to inform LTA on the disposal of decals.  - It is both an offence to drive a chauffeured PHC without displaying the decals and to affix/display the decals on a vehicle that is not a chauffeured PHC. The vehicle owner and driver could be liable to, upon conviction, i) a fine up to $1,000, or a jail term not exceeding 3 months, or both; ii) demerit points under the Vocational Licence Point System, where applicable.

content_question: where to find my commercial insurance?
meta_description: Hi! You may obtain the vehicle insurance details at our ONE.MOTORING portal via www.onemotoring.com.sg > Digital Servic... read more answers
content_answer: Hi! You may obtain the vehicle insurance details at our ONE.MOTORING portal via www.onemotoring.com.sg > Digital Services > Others > Enquire Vehicle Insurance Details at a fee of $7.49 (inclusive of GST) per successful search.  - Please note that you need to have a complete vehicle number including the prefix and suffix as well as a search (specific) date/time e.g. accident date/time. In addition, you would require a valid Credit / Debit Card (VISA or MasterCard only) or internet banking account with DBS, UOB, Standard Chartered Bank or Citibank (eNETS Debit) with adequate balance and Payment Limit for deduction of the fee.

content_question: Why can't I renew my road tax ?
meta_description: Hi William! Please ensure that you meet three pre-requisite for road tax renewal.  1. Ensure that your vehicle has va... read more answers
content_answer: Hi William! Please ensure that you meet three pre-requisite for road tax renewal.  1. Ensure that your vehicle has valid insurance coverage for the entire period you are paying road tax.  2. Vehicle inspection (If inspection is due)  If your vehicle is due for periodic inspection, you will receive an inspection notice about 3 months before your road tax expires.  Vehicle owners can still renew their road tax online for six months via OneMotoring, provided they have valid insurance coverage.  3. Pay any outstanding fines from LTA, HDB, URA and Traffic Police (TP)  Hope this helps!

content_question: What is my car omv
meta_description: Hi Tony! The OMV of a vehicle is basically the price paid or payable when a vehicle is imported into Singapore. This is... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Tony! The OMV of a vehicle is basically the price paid or payable when a vehicle is imported into Singapore. This is assessed by the Singapore Customs and includes purchase price, freight, insurance and all other charges incidental to the sale and delivery of the car to Singapore.  You can find out more information here: https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/content/onemotoring/home/buying/upfront-vehicle-costs/open-market-value--omv-.html#:~:text=The%20OMV%20of%20a%20vehicle,of%20the%20car%20to%20Singapore.

content_question: Hi, How can i pay my road tax by instalment by Diners club card
meta_description: Hi Juki! To use your Diners Club Card to pay your vehicle road tax, there are 2 ways. - 1. AXS m-Station (Mobile App... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Juki! To use your Diners Club Card to pay your vehicle road tax, there are 2 ways. - 1. AXS m-Station (Mobile App) Download the AXS App with Google Play or Apple Store STEPS: select Government \xe2\x80\x93> select LTA -> select Renew Road Tax -> enter Vehicle No., Owner ID, select Renewal Period -> confirm Account Details -> select Pay Now -> select Credit Cards & Diners Club -> input card details -> select Instalment 0% Interest & Repayment Period -> select OK -> select Submit -> input OTP -> Done! - 2. AXS e-Station (Website) AXS @ https://www.axs.com.sg STEPS: select LTA at left panel -> Renew Road Tax -> select I Agree -> enter Vehicle No., Owner ID, select Renewal Period -> select Credit Card & Diners Club -> input card details -> select Instalment 0% Interest & Repayment Period -> select OK -> select Submit -> input OTP -> Done! - For more information, visit this website: https://www.dinersclub.com.sg/money-matters/road-tax

content_answer: Hi Claire! content_question: First time selling my car here, any advice on what I should look out for?
meta_description: Hi Claire! If you are planning to sell to dealers or do a trade-in, beware of dealers who are looking to buy your car a... read more answers
content_answer: Get a quotation from multiple sources! You can use https://www.motorist.sg/car-valuation to do this. Make sure you're getting a good price out of it. Secondly, once the offer is made, take a deposit to secure the offer and negotiate the handover if you require extra time. Third, let the dealer/buyer know if there are any outstanding bank loans to be settled, dealers can do it for you after the handover but if it's a direct buyer you will need to pay the bank in full before the transaction. Lastly, make sure you receive full payment before you handover your car and keys. If there are bank payments to be made, the dealer has 8 days to sort this out will pay the bank after the handover normally to complete the transaction

content_question: Does the number of previous owners matter when buying a used car?
content_answer: Hi Anne. When there is only one owner previous for a used car, we would know about all the modifications or lack thereof done to that car and how well it has been taken care of because we can get that information from this one owner. Contrast to a car owned by 6 people before, there's no saying what the previous owners could've done to modify on the car and contacting all 6 of them to ask about the car is not really feasible. In the event of a break down the latter car would have much higher complications due to the high number of unknown modifications. So generally the number of owners do affect the pricing of certain vehicles.

content_question: How can foreign car register for road tax in singapore
meta_description: Hi Fion!  An Autopass Card is used to record your vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s entry into Singapore and to pay all entry and exit fees wh... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Fion!  An Autopass Card is used to record your vehicle\xe2\x80\x99s entry into Singapore and to pay all entry and exit fees when your vehicle exits Singapore. - Your Autopass Card is linked to your vehicle and contains its insurance and road tax expiry date. It cannot be transferred to another vehicle so you cannot use an Autopass Card for another vehicle. Your Autopass Card becomes invalid if the road tax or insurance recorded in the card has expired. - If you are applying for a VP, you can collect your Autopass Card at the same time. - To apply for an Autopass Card, you can submit a request with the following documents via LTA's online feedback form at www.lta.gov.sg/feedback. Please select the \xe2\x80\x9cVehicle Matters\xe2\x80\x9d category and the \xe2\x80\x9cAutopass, Vehicle Entry Permits and tolls\xe2\x80\x9d sub-category for your application to be processed more promptly. - LTA will reply to you via email with an appointment date and time to visit our LTA Customer Service Centre at 10 Sin Ming Drive S575701. Do bring along the documents specified in the email.  You must obtain approval at LTA's Customer Service Centre before driving into Singapore or transporting the vehicle into Singapore via air/sea. -  For more information: https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/content/onemotoring/home/driving/entering_and_exiting_singapore/foreign-vehicles-not-registered-in-malaysia.html

content_question: What are the penalties of a hit and run?
meta_description: Hello there! Under 304A, hit and run is a non-bailable offense, and an individual can be convicted by lifetime imprison... read more answers
content_answer: Hello there! Under 304A, hit and run is a non-bailable offense, and an individual can be convicted by lifetime imprisonment. In extreme cases, the police may also report a hit and drive case under 302, which is a section related to the murder. A driver booked under Section 302, may face a death sentence or life imprisonment.

content_answer: Hi Erica, 5 year COE premiums are 2 times cheaper than 10 year COE premiums. Whereas if you have a 10 year COE you can still continue to renew after the 10 year COE period. Motorist can help you determine the best course of action for your motorcycle COE or your car COE as well as help apply for a loan. content_question: Besides sending a used car for evaluation before buying, how do I know whether the used car have been involved in accident before?
meta_description: If you are using VICOM VFIT for evaluation, they will most likely be able to identify if a car has been in an accident.... read more answers
content_answer: If you are using VICOM VFIT for evaluation, they will most likely be able to identify if a car has been in an accident. The paint thickness is being tested and if there are any repairs done before, the paint will show inconsistency. They will also check if nuts and bolts of the different car parts have signs of removal. This is pretty much all that can be done to attempt to check if this is a car that was in an accident.   There are no other options available and insurance companies will not reveal such information to the public.

content_question: any lta passed exhaust pipe ?
meta_description: Hi Ben! You can make and manage appointments for appeals on vehicle modification and inspection matters at LTA Customer... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Ben! You can make and manage appointments for appeals on vehicle modification and inspection matters at LTA Customer Service Centre, 10 Sin Ming Drive, via their Digital Services at the following link: https://go.gov.sg/lta-eappointment - For the exhaust system, which consists of the exhaust manifold, catalytic converter and muffler, is used as part of a vehicle's exhaust-emission control system to ensure that the exhaust emission meets environmental standards. Before modifying the exhaust system, you need to get LTA\xe2\x80\x99s approval by submitting these for evaluation:   Certification from the product manufacturer stating that the proposed aftermarket exhaust system is suitable for the make and model of the vehicle Test reports from LTA- or NEA-recognised test laboratories to show that the aftermarket exhaust system, when fitted to your vehicle, complies with noise and exhaust emission standards for your vehicle model You are not allowed to remove catalytic converters and mufflers, as it will adversely affect the exhaust emission characteristics of the vehicle.   More information is available here: https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/content/onemotoring/home/owning/modification.html

content_question: why fuel consumption can drop suddenly ( 14km /1L to 10km /1L . must change bmaf/map sensor or spark plugs to iridium), ?
meta_description: Hi there! The engine may be fine but the crucial components that contribute to the combustion cycle could be faulty. Fo... read more answers
content_answer: Hi there! The engine may be fine but the crucial components that contribute to the combustion cycle could be faulty. For instance, a faulty spark plug or O2 sensor in a petrol engine and a dirty fuel injector in a diesel engine can cause more consumption of fuel resulting in low fuel mileage.  I would recommend you to visit a workshop for them to do the relevant tests!

content_question: Does current COE prices affect my used car price?
meta_description: Yes, it does. When COE goes up, demand for new cars falls and people look into used cars and can sometimes inflate the ... read more answers
content_answer: Yes, it does. When COE goes up, demand for new cars falls and people look into used cars and can sometimes inflate the price to more than what it usually is. So to answer your questions, market prices for the used car gets swayed by COE indirectly but the market price does not swing as fast as you would imagine

content_question: Does driving in military camps for revised off peak car require an e-day license given that military areas are not considered as public roads?
meta_description: Goes back to the rule of "do but don't get caught". LTA has no business within military camps and hence they can't catc... read more answers
content_answer: Goes back to the rule of "do but don\'t get caught". LTA has no business within military camps and hence they can\'t catch you there. You can decide on your own if you want to get the day license.   Military camps belong to the state, which technically is the government or public property. Saying that roads within the camp are not considered public roads is not exactly correct.  Cheers.

content_question: How do I apply for the $80 Petrol Duty Rebates for motorcycles?
meta_description: Hi Amir, LTA will disburse the additional PDR in cash progressively from mid-May, through GIRO or PayNow (NRIC). No app... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Amir, LTA will disburse the additional PDR in cash progressively from mid-May, through GIRO or PayNow (NRIC). No application is required. Owners will be notified via SMS when the additional PDR has been credited to their bank accounts.  Individual owners with more than one motorcycle will receive road tax rebates for each motorcycle, but only one payout of the additional PDR based on the higher quantum among the eligible motorcycles.  Individual motorcycle owners who wish to receive the additional PDR via GIRO should ensure that they update their bank account details on LTA\xe2\x80\x99s website at go.gov.sg/ltaupdate by 15 May 2021.

content_question: What are some tips when dealing with dealerships when buying cars?
meta_description: Hi Jerome, these are some tips when buying from dealerships. 1. Do your research. Start with knowing what similar vehi... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Jerome, these are some tips when buying from dealerships. 1. Do your research. Start with knowing what similar vehicles have sold for so you can make an informed decision on the vehicle you\xe2\x80\x99re interested in. 2. Consider other factors. There are several other things that can influence the selling price of a car such as colour, if it was smoked in, wear and tear on the interior, etc. and you can use these to negotiate the selling price. 3. Don\xe2\x80\x99t rush the decision. If the seller makes a counteroffer and you\xe2\x80\x99d like to think about it, let the seller know as buying a car is a big decision and not one you want to rush into.  4. Be prepared to walk away. There are plenty of options out there when it comes to buying a used car. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get too attached to the vehicle, especially if you and the seller can\xe2\x80\x99t come to a deal. Finally if you'd like you could head over to the url below to try these tips on us :). https://www.motorist.sg/used-cars

content_question: How does current coe price affect coe renewal price?
meta_description: Hi Adilah, COE renewal prices are affected by the past three months of COE premiums. This average is also known as the ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Adilah, COE renewal prices are calculated by averaging the past three months of COE premiums. This average is also known as the Prevailing Quota Premium (PQP). For example, the April CAT A COE PQP is the average of the CAT A COE price from January, February and March. If you want to renew your coe you can head over to the url below so that our helpful associates can assist you. https://www.motorist.sg/coe-renewal

content_question: What happens if I don't renew my COE?
meta_description: Hello Aditya!   If you do not renew your COE, your vehicle will be deregistered and will need to be scrapped.  Rene... read more answers
content_answer: Hello Aditya!   If you do not renew your COE, your vehicle will be deregistered and will need to be scrapped.  Renewal should and can be done before your existing COE expires. It can also be done one month after the COE expiry date. However, you won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to drive your vehicle until the COE has been renewed.  In addition, you will also be charged with a late payment fee. You can click on this link as well to check out the different fees. https://www.motorist.sg/article/23/a-car-owner-s-guide-to-coe-renewal-from-pqp-to-renewal-duration  Kindly note that car owners who fail to renew their COE within one month of their COE expiry will have to scrap their car immediately.

meta_description: They will issue the notice of traffic offence once the driver particulars have been established; if not a warning. You ... read more answers
content_answer: They will issue the notice of traffic offence once the driver particulars have been established; if not a warning. You may want to appeal thereafter if based on your good record.

content_question: Is it illegal to play YouTube videos through my front player for my passengers while driving?
meta_description: Best not to, as it is still a distraction. In the RTA S65B(3d), it is specified that "sending or receiving audio or vid... read more answers
content_answer: Best not to, as it is still a distraction. In the RTA S65B(3d), it is specified that "sending or receiving audio or video files as a form of communitive function is an offence, and is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or to both".  Watching a video on your dashboard can be interpreted as receiving a video  and you may be implicated on contravening the above section, whether the video is meant for the passenger or yourself.  Best to have a dedicated player for your passenger(s).

content_question: Eligible motorcycle owners will receive $80 (up to 200cc) or $50 (201 to 400cc) additional Petrol Duty Rebate. content_answer: Hi Arun! Did you register by 16 February 2021? If not you can call LTA at 1800 2255 582 or contact them via www.lta.gov.sg/feedback to get more info! - The PDR will be paid to all eligible individual owners of motorcycles registered as at the close of 16 February 2021. Individual owners with more than one motorcycle will receive road tax rebates for each motorcycle, but only one payout of the additional PDR based on the higher quantum among the eligible motorcycles. - Individual motorcycle owners who wish to receive the additional PDR via GIRO should ensure that they update their bank account details on LTA\xe2\x80\x99s website at go.gov.sg/ltaupdate (or via the attached QR code) by 15 May 2021. https://www.lta.gov.sg/content/ltagov/en/newsroom/2021/2/news-releases/road_tax_and_petrol_duty_rebates.html

content_question: How do I know if there is a red-light camera ahead of me on the road or nearing a traffic light?
meta_description: Hello Adeline! With the Motorist application, you will be able to check for red cameras and be notified when you are ap... read more answers
content_answer: Hello Adeline! With the Motorist application, you will be able to check for red cameras and be notified when you are approaching one.   Under the \xe2\x80\x9cDashboard\xe2\x80\x9d tab and under \xe2\x80\x9cDrive\xe2\x80\x9d you can click on \xe2\x80\x9cCo-Driver\xe2\x80\x9d. Switch on your notifications and you will be notified with real-time audio alerts when approaching different points of interest, in this case, red light cameras.   There are also other cameras such as the Fixed Speed Camera, Mobile Speed Camera, Police Speed Laser Camera and Average Speed Camera.  Under \xe2\x80\x9cTraffic Incidents\xe2\x80\x9d, you are also able to access a map with different icons on it. You can click on the Red Light Camera icons and check if there are any ahead of you.  You can download our application here: https://www.motorist.sg/app-WeRe

content_question: Is there a way for me to see the petrol price comparison over the weeks and months?
meta_description: Hello Christian! Yes there is. You can do so via the Motorist application. You can first download the application via t... read more answers
content_answer: Hello Christian! Yes there is. You can do so via the Motorist application. You can first download the application via this link: https://www.motorist.sg/app-WeRe  You can then check the fuel prices under the DashBoard tab where you scroll down to find \xe2\x80\x9cDrive\xe2\x80\x9d. Under that, you should be able to see \xe2\x80\x9cFuel Prices\xe2\x80\x9d. Simply click on that and you will be brought over to the fuel prices for the different petrol companies.  Scroll down a little and you will see \xe2\x80\x9cFuel Prices Trend\xe2\x80\x9d. This gives you the different prices for the different fuel types (92, 95, 98, Diesel, Premium) for each petrol company (Esso, Shell, SPC, Caltex, Sinopec) in Singapore over a span of 6 months, 12 months and 24 months.  However, as of now, we only have data as early as May 21st on the application. We will make sure to update any changes or trends once there is any.

content_question: Pqp for July cat B how much?
meta_description: Hello Justin!   The PQP is calculated by taking the moving average of COE prices in the last 3 months. This means tha... read more answers
content_answer: Hello Justin!   The PQP is calculated by taking the moving average of COE prices in the last 3 months. This means that the PQP will change every month. As of now, the latest PQP dates back to May 2021.   However, you can click on this link (https://www.motorist.sg/coe-results/) and keep a lookout for the release of PQP for July 2021.  You can also read an article that Motorist wrote about COE prices and everything you need to know about it. Here is the link: https://www.motorist.sg/article/23/a-car-owner-s-guide-to-coe-renewal-from-pqp-to-renewal-duration

content_question: What\xe2\x80\x99s LTA website to convert my Private hire insurance to Z10 or Z11
meta_description: Hi Thomas, login to OneMotoring https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/, click on the \xe2\x80\x98Ownership\xe2\x80\x99 tab, followed by \xe2\x80\x98Vehicle Sch... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Thomas, login to OneMotoring https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/, click on the \xe2\x80\x98Ownership\xe2\x80\x99 tab, followed by \xe2\x80\x98Vehicle Scheme/Specifications\xe2\x80\x99, then the \xe2\x80\x98Convert my vehicle scheme\xe2\x80\x99 option. Under \xe2\x80\x98Conversion Type\xe2\x80\x99, select the drop-down option \xe2\x80\x98Passenger Car to Private Hire (Chauffeur) \xe2\x80\x93 P to Z\xe2\x80\x99.  Once selected, you\xe2\x80\x99ll need your vehicle license plate number, and make a payment of S$100. Kindly note that you\xe2\x80\x99ll need to pay another $100 if you plan to change your vehicle class back for personal use only.  If you need more information on applying for being a PHV driver you can head to our article https://www.motorist.sg/article/226/how-to-drive-for-grab .

meta_description: Hi Leonard according to OneMotoring, you have to renew your road tax if it expires before you sell or deregister your v... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Leonard according to OneMotoring, you have to renew your road tax if it expires before you sell or deregister your vehicle. When a vehicle is sold, any road tax that has been paid will follow the vehicle and be transferred to the new owner. You can consider factoring in the unused road tax into the selling price of your vehicle.

content_question: I currently have a plate number retained from my scrapped car. I want to register this retained plate number onto a new car I have purchased under my company name. The new car is not yet registered. How do I go about using the retained car plate at the point of registration for my new vehicle?
meta_description: Hi Bryan, You need to inform your motor dealer to use your retained VRN on your new vehicle, before it is registered an... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Bryan, You need to inform your motor dealer to use your retained VRN on your new vehicle, before it is registered and automatically assigned a number. Your motor dealer will then help you register your new vehicle with the retained VRN. Please note that once a vehicle is assigned a vehicle number, it will not be considered a new vehicle. You can find out more at https://onemotoring.lta.gov.sg/content/onemotoring/home/selling-deregistering/retain-replace-vrn.htm

content_question: Red light camera locations
meta_description: Hi Raj, you may refer to the attached link for the locations of the red light cameras in Singapore: https://www.police.... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Raj, you may refer to the attached link for the locations of the red light cameras in Singapore: https://www.police.gov.sg/~/media/spf/images/newsreleases/2014/20141111_traff_digital_red_light_camera_annexb.pdf   Alternatively, with the Motorist application, you will be able to check for red cameras and be notified when you are approaching one.   Under the \xe2\x80\x9cDashboard\xe2\x80\x9d tab and under \xe2\x80\x9cDrive\xe2\x80\x9d you can click on \xe2\x80\x9cCo-Driver\xe2\x80\x9d. Switch on your notifications and you will be notified with real-time audio alerts when approaching different points of interest, in this case, red light cameras. There are also other cameras such as the Fixed Speed Camera, Mobile Speed Camera, Police Speed Laser Camera and Average Speed Camera.  Under \xe2\x80\x9cTraffic Incidents\xe2\x80\x9d, you are also able to access a map with different icons on it. You can click on the Red Light Camera icons and check if there are any ahead of you.

content_question: Can we transfer PHV decal from car to car due to change of vehicle?
meta_description: Hi Hock Soon, the decals are not transferrable across vehicles, and must not be removed unless the vehicles cease to be... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Hock Soon, the PHV/PHC decals are not transferrable across vehicles, and must not be removed unless the vehicles cease to be chauffeured private hire cars. If you wish, it\xe2\x80\x99s best that you visit any Vicom, JIC or STA inspection centres to get the decals affixed on your vehicle that you have switched to. It will cost you $20, including GST, to get them affixed.  You may read one of our articles where we have written a portion about PHV/PHC Decals (Why transferring of decals is illegal and how we can get PHV/PHC decals affixed etc. All the information you need!) here: https://www.motorist.sg/article/226/how-to-drive-for-grab

content_question: Are you able to assist with a foreign vehicle accident claim
meta_description: Hi Raj, we're sorry to hear about this. We can't assist you in foreign vehicle accident claim but we can give you some ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Raj, we're sorry to hear about this. We can't assist you in foreign vehicle accident claim but we can give you some advice.  You will require the aid of a lawyer, as legal suits against Malaysian insurers have to be filed in the Singapore High Court.  Your claim process may take some time, as the matter will involve identifying and locating a foreign party. However, once the other party has been located and the Malaysian insurers have been identified, the matter will proceed more smoothly.  If you wish to make a claim against the other party\xe2\x80\x99s Malaysian insurers, prepare and submit the following documents to your lawyers: Police report A police sketch plan and key (if available) Police investigation results (if available) Vehicle registration card (photocopy) Photocopy of Certificate of Insurance, policy schedule, or Cover Note Photocopy of Identity card Repair bill & proof of payment Rental car bill (if the car was rented) Proof of losses incurred A vehicle surveyor report with original photographs All other bills and receipts for expenses due to the accident We wish you best of luck.

content_question: COE price low should renew first or wait?
meta_description: Hi Josiah, if your car is expiring soon we recommend you don't renew early as you forfeit your remaining COE and if pri... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Josiah you have two options,  If your COE expires in 5 August 2021 for example  1. Renew before expiry month  If you choose to renew your COE for five years, you will have to deregister your car when it expires.  You can find out the PQP for July 2021 after the second bidding exercise in June 2021.  You can renew your COE using the July 2021 PQP on the Friday after the second bidding exercise in June 2021. Your new COE period will start on 1 August 2021. In this case, you have until the end of July to do this. *Note that the unused portion of your COE will be forfeited (including COE rebates)  2. Renew in expiry month  \xe2\x80\xa2 You can find out the PQP for August 2021 after the second bidding exercise in July 2021, and renew your COE on the Friday after the second bidding exercise in July 2021. \xe2\x80\xa2 Your COE period will start the day after your current COE expires (which in this case is 6 August 2021)  \xe2\x80\xa2 You will have until the end of your COE to do this. (5 August)  You can head over to the URL below to get our friendly associates to assist you in your decision. https://www.motorist.sg/coe-renewal

content_question: What affects COE prices?
meta_description: Hi Jerrica, the Current COE Price (CCP) is the price of the highest unsuccessful bid plus $1. The number of successful ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Jerrica, the Current COE Price (CCP) is the price of the highest unsuccessful bid plus $1. The number of successful bidders is limited by the COEs available for each particular COE category. The bid is in the running as long as the reserve price is equal to or higher than the CCP. If you are interested to renew your COE, you can head over to the url below so that our friendly associates can be in touch. https://www.motorist.sg/coe-renewal

content_question: Penalty for not wearing helmet
meta_description: Hi Faizan, if you're talking about not wearing helmet on a motorbike under the current law, first-time offenders could ... read more answers
content_answer: Hi Faizan, if you're talking about not wearing helmet on a motorbike under the current law, first-time offenders could be jailed for up to three months and/or fined up to S$500. Repeat offenders could be jailed for up to six months and/or fined up to S$1,000.

content_question: Can cyclists go on the Bartley Road East viaduct?
meta_description: Hi David, according to the Road Traffic Act (Cap. 276), Road Traffic (Expressways \xe2\x80\x94 Excluded Vehicles) Rules 2010, bicy... read more answers
content_answer: Hi David, according to the Road Traffic Act (Cap. 276), Road Traffic (Expressways \xe2\x80\x94 Excluded Vehicles) Rules 2010, bicycles are prohibited on expressways.   Cyclists are allowed to cycle on Bartley Viaduct, Keppel Viaduct, Labrador Viaduct, Lornie Viaduct, MacRitchie Viaduct, Serangoon Viaduct, Tampines Viaduct, and Woodlands Checkpoint Viaduct.  Except for Tuas Viaduct, which cyclists aren't allowed to cycle on.
